or private and nonprofit groups who also want to reach the public. In the actual selling of products, however, marketing people generally stay in the private sector. Frequently they get into selling through previous experience in marketing. However, there are many positions, such as sales management, that are only available to those who are trained in, and experienced at, marketing.
Another consideration is that private sector employers who are interested in salespeople usually want trained, experienced marketing people, whether they directly involved in marketing or not. The reason for this interest is that company-wide improvements in sales can be promoted by personnel who have extensive marketing experience and training. And marketers are likely to know company products and prospects for them in the particular marketing area they have background in. So an employer needs to find an experienced marketing person with strong on-the-job experience to develop and implement sales programs.

The family house on Sulome Street, Mourneh, is humble, the yard only just large enough for a football pitch and a small chicken coup cluttered with eggs. Like all the houses there they are clinically clean; their tenant is Dr Emilie Tomimtam. Keeping her two standards apart takes some spiritual effort – habits bred at UCC are a long way from the cleaning rituals of these remote mountains, the barricade with gold outlines that comes first, then, only afterward, any brushing, washing – yet she manages it, straddling the divide.
Taking tea there, there's a folk quality about the entire place – women march around in black and pearls and men wear suits and ties, though

you can eat to help relieve and stop your diarrhea. Generally, no single treatment is going to work for everybody. In particular, while some foods are likely to help with your diarrhea, many will not. So, you will need to make some adjustments during the course of severe diarrhea to find the diet that works best for you.
Can variety help you manage diarrhea? Eating a variety of foods of the right weight helps your body stay as hydrated as possible. You do not need to eat unusual amounts of food. But, variety helps ensure steady, reliable comfort and avoid familiar foods that might stop working during repeated episodes of diarrhea.

Unsurprisingly, the United States also leads the world in caesareans, with 34% of births involving caesarean surgery – the most in the world. A caesarean is an absolute necessity when the mother and/or baby is at risk in childbirth. Definite benefits have been seen from the relatively recent trend of performing elective caesareans solely to facilitate a vaginal delivery. However, some research has shown that routine medical interventions can create more harm than good in the process. Medicalization from pregnancy to birth can be parented in tandem with an increased likelihood of many maternal deaths.

of mid-green or bronze-green, fragrant foliage which is equally at home in winter containers as it is in summer borders. One of the basic problems of the current food, energy, transport and housing systems rests in the distance between production and consumption, as David Suzuki argued in his article Low-hanging fruit solutions for cutting our greenhouse gas emissions. Such a system allows distant effects to be managed or ignored by those who cause them. The new ordinance took effect 30 days after the April 9 vote. At press time, the city did not yet have any cannabis business applications on file.
Redwood City adopted a limited ban on marijuana retail in June 2016, which remained in force through 2017. Middle Ages. As the first Christian Platonic philosopher, he influenced a vast number of thinkers, including Augustine, whom he deeply influenced by his famous Ergo cogito (‘Therefore, I think’).
Shoham exhibits Proclus in conversation with 21st-century philosophers, illuminating his arguments for their acceptance. In doing so, the book performs two tasks: it offers an extensive presentation of Proclus’ philosophical system, allowing the contemporary reader to evaluate his claims, and it assists the developing historian of ideas to form an understating of the development of Greek philosophy from Plato to the Beginnings of Christianity. The whole philosophical system is presented here, most completely and accurately. Indeed, it is a system that seemed to be lost for all time, existing in the fragmentary writings of Proclus’ disciples, or in only one entire work, the Commentary on Plato

. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches its destination. Here are a few tips for proper business envelope addressing.
Business envelopes should always be addressed and properly stamped so they are ready for receipt by the recipient. Once you’ve chosen a letterhead and begun to write your letter, take your time to write down all recipient names. If you don’t know the full name of a person or the name of their position within the company’s organization, you might need to send an additional envelope or package with multiple letters which are addressed to different people. Sanford ruled that Prixon and Tower are co-owners according to Ohio law, so the prize money would be split evenly. Both women -- and their attorneys -- immediately pounced on her judgment, because it's tied to state law and would require some negotiating between Orange and Cleveland counties. But Ohio's state lottery director, C. Richard Krasiian, said it is under federal review and will not be subject to state law until the federal government makes its ruling.

Jere Jackson Melo, who represented Ward 2 on the Fort Bragg city council for six years and served as mayor for four, was born Feb. 15, 1950, to Albino Luna Melo and Violet Jean Jackson in Santa Maria, Calif.
Jere served as mayor of Fort Bragg and on the Fort Bragg City Council from 1986 until 1996. After a few years of working on his ranch, he was re-elected in 2004 and began serving once again as city councilman.
Jere lived his life putting his family first. He was best known for his devotion to his children (four sons, one daughter and two stepsons) and his grandchildren

A massive car bomb exploded just beyond his view seconds later.
For a moment, Fort Riley soldier Simmons, 25, didn’t realize what just happened.
About 10 minutes later, the highest-ranking Army officer involved in the battle of Najaf relayed the news: Simmons, an intelligence specialist on the Military Transition Team, an interagency project run from Iraqi police headquarters by agents of the FBI, was the victim of friendly fire.

A new super-resolution X-ray imaging technique has been developed by a team of engineers from the University of Wisconsin–Madison and Larxdom in Germany. It uses a smaller, more portable X-ray source to peer through about a millimeter of tissue. Bitcoin on Jan. 1, 2009, was about $0.0009; trades were measured in pennies. The cryptocurrency surged to its historic peak of $17,000 during the 12 months that ended Dec. 31, according to Futuresize.
So what’s pushed Bitcoin above its heady price of late?
The U.S. President Donald Trump election is cited by many experts for the spike. Market players on the dashboards were cautious or skeptical during the campaign and barely flirted with speculation. Some even likened it to a Ponzi scheme.

––in metal wire or the bulk crystalline state––to move in predictable ways. Such is not the case with two-dimensional (2D) materials built on a honeycomb lattice. Instead, the electronic properties of 2D materials depend on local interactions and need to be understood by extending the notion of crystalline order to include features of entanglement and qubit-like degrees of freedom.
The visual analogy of local information clusters—confined regions of coherent light in time and space—has been used to represent dark state-like electron properties in atomically thin crystalline metals. These local conglomerations of entangled electron spins come in a range of sizes and compositions. In other words, there’s not a single photonic analog to qubit-like object. Instead, successfully manipulating qubits requires assembling new types of fluorescent materials with which to construct them.

The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU rules can be if they are enforced properly. The procedure stops carmakers from meeting technical regulations with technology designed to cheat engine tests.
The procedure, known in Brussels as “Portugal testing,” is a low cost feature used by car manufacturers since the 1990s to trigger Type-approvals in the European Union. It was established by a legal loophole recognising the adoption of law by the EU, and its application to new models is justified by an administrative note of the Commission. The procedure is presently used to enable industrial players, such as Fiat-Chrysler, Renault and Toyota, among others, to reduce the laboratories’ costs for testing new car models and at the same time increase their sales.
But the European Commission has never used the powers it has over the tests.

. In India, economic factors like inflation, high household debt loads and sluggish bank credit are jeopardizing consumers’ appetites for high-end goods.
For a decade since the worldwide financial crisis, China was the darling of U.S. companies looking for the next big thing. Rising incomes from an ascending middle class were fuelling the market for costlier generics, electronics, consumer durables and food.
India — by some accounts the world’s next-most populous nation after China — had investors’ imagination fired by the shared belief that its demographic makeup favoured the growth of a rapidly expanding middle class. But as global economic growth slows and trade protectionism rises, the strong tail winds of increasing growth and rising consumption that countries like India and China were basking in have begun to slow to a stiff breeze of anxiety.

Dominican nationality. The DR’s Constitution stipulates that foreign born descendants of slaves who attain Dominican citizenship are able to pass down their Dominican citizenship to their children. But in 2008 the Dominican DR amended its Constitution, specifically barring children born of illegal migrants from automatically inheriting Dominican nationality unless they can prove permanent residency and labor registration certificates. These certificates are require only for legal migrant workers (including migrants who over-stay their tourist visas to work illegally). Children born of illegally migrant mothers are thus stripped of their Dominican nationality through no fault of their own, not even being aware that they are not Dominicans despite being raised in the Dominican Republic.

Cynic or idealist, San Francisco voters overwhelmingly supported a record $310 million annual spending increase for affordable housing, more than six years after devastating ballot initiatives 2 and 3 that slashed more than $300 million from housing plans approved over 10 years. the issue of racial inequality is rarely debated. And that lack of debate shapes our understanding of the world around us. From how we vote to which corporations we put our money in, the lens through which we process inequality and other important issues is skewed.
Native Americans Dwarfed
For instance, take the issue of Native Americans in the US. Many have been experiencing high levels of poverty as do many of us. The challenge is that they exist at an insurmountable disadvantage when it comes to political and economic matters.
According to the most recent US Census released in August 2012, 5.5 percent of the US population identifies itself as Native American. In cementing the reputation of it as this neglected minority, Native Americans faced a 24 percent poverty rate, considerably higher than the rate faced by Hispanic, black and white households. the east coast a new initiative is being trialed that will protect livestock, the environment and help to save water on farms.
A new initiative, called HerdSense, is a sensor is fitted to the neck of a cow, taking measurements via eight sensors that distribute through the animal’s skin.
The cows are monitored to maintain their fitness and health, helping farmers to stay on top of management issues.
The technology is currently available in three states; Western Australia, South Australia and New South Wales. The trial project is available in New South Wales’ Fairfield cattle stud, operated by Nathanael Landgren. All the data obtained by the system is first structure and then connected by a WiFi network to a computer that uploads all the information to a cloud file that’s located in New South Wales.

On a number of occasions US President Donald Trump has expressed strong opposition to anything that might potentially reduce economic relations between the two Irelands and any idea that would weaken the United States' support for the political union for Northern Ireland and the Republic.
The 1972 Anglo-Irish agreement permitted both Irish states to re-establish closer diplomatic, security and free trade links but did not cover issues such as immigration and border controls. It was never intended to achieve a unity of the two islands.
There was no real surprise for anyone in Dublin or Belfast when newer border arrangements were outlined in the Brexit white paper but there is a deadlock that has essentially been precipitated by the Irish Border Committee set up with a mandate to prevent the seeps in trade. Transportation is getting more expensive everywhere you look.

there's a lot of confusion when it comes to determining what FODMAPs are. Let’s dive in and figure out what they are and why everyone’s talking about them…
The term FODMAP is an acronym for - Fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols
Fera nteible oligosaccharides are small molecules of sugars found in a variety of different foods (Fructose, Galactose and Fructan)
Disaccharides are molecules of sugars linked together that are found in a variety of foods (D-Sugars and Lactose).
Monosaccharides are single sugars found in a variety of foods (Fructose, Galactose and Lactose)
Polyols are small molecules of sugars found in foods such as berries

“Concussion” means that a “child has been hit in the head or a blow to the body has caused the brain to move rapidly back and forth inside the skull. Symptoms usually come on suddenly, within minutes or an hour after the injury, and may include headache, feeling dazed, problems remembering and concentrating, feeling unsteady, and nausea” the CDC says.
Concussion symptoms last on average about three weeks, but full recovery takes three to 12 months, which “means even actions like brushing teeth and eating can be challenging,” the CDC warns. In fact, research shows that even kids who lose consciousness can have a concussion. And CDC officials say that children who experience repeated head blows over a short period could be at greater risk for long-term problems like memory loss.

of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many who have been profoundly touched by nature, John Muir was an unconventional man with an unquenchable thirst for adventure and learning. He felt a strong affinity for nature, and sought to explore broad swaths of the continent using their power for his survival and gaining a first-hand understanding of the movement of the world. Muir left home to study at the University of Wisconsin, but soon ran away in search of the world. His jailbreak eventually carried him to the wilds of the North American landscapes. During his youthful explorations, Muir also discovered a passion for scientific discovery and applied technology. Eventually, this unusual approach to education stirred his Revolutionary soul as he worked tirelessly to preserve wilder and ever-wilder swaths of earth as part of the world-renowned parks service

affaele Grillo of INAF-OACT in Bologna, Italy, succeeded in resolving the central star cluster in one of our biggest globular clusters, the so-called M4. Its resolution is comparable to the lensing resolution of planetary nebulae like the planetary nebulae of NGC?4372 at the heart of M82.
It is the first time that astronomers have been able to resolve such a massive cluster at their heart. Astronomers dubbed it the ‘M4 clump’ (or MACHO). Motivated by theories on hierarchical formation of clustered and solitary stellar systems, its extreme mass satisfies all the selection criteria of their stellar halo progenitors: high central density, high mass, and an old age. Therefore, the MACHO might be considered as the result of co-evolution between the globular cluster and massive galaxies.

Those data will be compared with other similar data collected over its history. NOAA says it has enough volunteers registered to collect data over a 50-mile by 50-mile grid in the area of totality (where it is fully dark).
The eclipse map published by NOAA has a zoom-able feature.

Cashew nuts have been a staple food in Tanzania, the fifth largest producer and grower worldwide, for decades and farmers struggle to fetch a good price in informal markets during the harvest season.
The market price fluctuates depending on supply and demand and quality varieties. On Monday, a kilo of cashew nuts fetched 12,218 shillings ($4.95) in wholesale markets - slightly below last week’s levels, which indicates that there are enough nuts in Tanzania.
Tanzanian cashew nuts are usually exported to Europe in bulk and prices there have been consistent and are likely to remain so.
Since 2012, more than 79,000-metric tonnes (MT) of dry cashew nuts have been exported every year

General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a sweeping plan to protect the privacy and confidentiality of EU citizens’ data, officially goes into effect May 25. As the EU’s data protection framework, the GDPR affects anyone who does business in Europe.
Many US-based businesses don’t take a hard look at data protection until they cross over the Atlantic into the EU. Even if your company operates under strict US state, federal, or industry privacy laws, you’ll need to take a look at those laws and make sure your operation complies with the GDPR. The good and bad news: Fines for not complying with GDPR are steep. The good news is, complying is easier and more painless than you’d think. Adopting safe business practices helps ensure your organization is doing everything it can to protect data.

First, there was a lot of hype about the tax reduction for individual taxpayers. However, it is certainly a step in the right direction. The FM articulated that one crore will benefit and indirectly, it meant 3.67 crore taxpayers will benefit assuredly. The tax reduction up to Rs 5 lakh per annum for taxable income between Rs 3lakhs to Rs 10 lakhs is expected to benefit 2.71 crore individuals. An average tax liability for this group is likely around Rs 13,000 and an average income is likely to be around Rs 5.7 lakhs. Under the old scheme, an income tax of Rs 2,270 was charged on an annual income of Rs 5.7 Lakh. With new tax regime, an average annual income will be around Rs 1.73%

Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies or private and nonprofit groups who also want to reach the public. In the actual selling of products, however, marketing people generally stay in the private sector. Frequently they get into selling through previous experience in marketing. However, there are many positions, such as sales management, that are only available to those who are trained in, and experienced at, marketing.
Another consideration is that private sector employers who are interested in salespeople usually want trained, experienced marketing people, whether they directly involved in marketing or not. The reason for this interest is that company-wide improvements in sales can be promoted by personnel who have extensive marketing experience and training. And marketers are likely to know company products and prospects for them in the particular marketing area they have background in. So an employer needs to find an experienced marketing person with strong on-the-job experience to develop and implement sales programs.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a division of the WHO, has released its evaluation of over 800 potential carcinogens, and concluded that processed meat causes bowel cancers and a type of muscle cancer called leiomyosarcoma.
According to the report, eating 50g of processed meat a day (the equivalent of one hotdog or two bangers and mash) can potentially increase a man's risk of colon cancer by 18 percent and a woman's risk of developing cancer of the bowel by 10 percent.
New York Times health writer Jane E. Brody puts it in context:
“Carcinogens are chemicals or physical agents whose presence in and exposure of the body may induce or alter the development of a general category of malignant cancer called 'sarcomas.'

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican/conservative and Democratic policymakers.
Americans will either see their nation’s credit rating downgraded or face a partial government shutdown in the fall and early winter months when funding for major federal programs expires, Lew warned at the weekend in a Reuters Newsmaker event, in which he also said that without a long-term revenue solution - a step used by previous Congresses to raise the U.S. debt ceiling - the United States could face fiscal Armageddon.
"The choices we face as a country are enormous. We cannot allow them to be constrained by political gridlock," said Lew, who will assume the Senate seat of the late Democrat John D. Rockefeller in January.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods you can eat to help relieve and stop your diarrhea. Generally, no single treatment is going to work for everybody. In particular, while some foods are likely to help with your diarrhea, many will not. So, you will need to make some adjustments during the course of severe diarrhea to find the diet that works best for you.
Can variety help you manage diarrhea? Eating a variety of foods of the right weight helps your body stay as hydrated as possible. You do not need to eat unusual amounts of food. But, variety helps ensure steady, reliable comfort and avoid familiar foods that might stop working during repeated episodes of diarrhea.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to bridge perennial, bitterly contentious Washington partisan divides, calling both Republicans and Democrats in Congress to ambitious bipartisan action on critical issues he described as "problems from potholes to prosperity."
A long-term fix for the debt could involve raised taxes on rich Americans or reforms of costly government programs. Efforts to do so likely will be vehemently resisted by congressional Republicans who will try to blunt such fiscal changes by demanding, in exchange, significant cuts in domestic spending.
So, the next months could be among the most strenuous periods for Obama's conducting of presidential partisan politics since Republican efforts to derail his presidency with allegations centering on his now-ended citizenship status.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely.
Unsurprisingly, the United States also leads the world in caesareans, with 34% of births involving caesarean surgery – the most in the world. A caesarean is an absolute necessity when the mother and/or baby is at risk in childbirth. Definite benefits have been seen from the relatively recent trend of performing elective caesareans solely to facilitate a vaginal delivery. However, some research has shown that routine medical interventions can create more harm than good in the process. Medicalization from pregnancy to birth can be parented in tandem with an increased likelihood of many maternal deaths.
There is no simple method that countries can borrow in order to avoid maternal and infant deaths. However, there are concrete ways that women (and their nurses, midwives and doctors) can

Wilson completed 15 of 25 passes for 183 yards this time.

Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue increased 6% in dollar terms to $6.45 billion (£4.60 billion) on a currency-neutral basis. A year earlier, Nike's revenue rose 2% in actual terms to $6 billion.

Product catalogue availability also contributed to the performance, with the brand owned by Foot Locker seeing a 16% increase in athletes walking into its stores, which contributed to a 10% spike in foot traffic only two months into the year.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, fragrant foliage which is equally at home in winter containers as it is in summer borders. Often grown in mats in a sunny patio pot, or cascading over surprisingly young low walls and containers the little spikes of purple blue or white flowers are held upright so even the most enthusiastic meanderer will reach these eye-catching little gems when passing.
Blossoming for ages ten weeks or more from mid-February to September these fantastic winter flowers rarely produce more than two flowers per stem but these long-stemmed inflorescences have the bonus effect of keeping some of the stiff foliage topping the stems.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Oxford, followed by a month in Eastern Europe. After meeting my great-great-grandfather's nearly-to-be-extinct Shand^)rian family in Poznán, Poland (60 miles north of Poznań, Poland, as the crow flies), I boarded an overnight train to Ljubljana, Slovenia.
I don't really remember much about that train ride. I didn't travel light; my luggage was heavy. But what I remember most was the beauty and the grandeur of the Alps. They were my ancestral home. At that time, the Alps felt like home.
Born in Germany (D-12), here growing up in Pasco, Washington (USA-141), and having visited Europe over 100 times, the mountains are still a moving, subject of awe and a sense of being "home".

Ukraine had previously sought to resell gas to European customers at a discounted rate, following a move by the European Community last year to give Ukraine the right to market gas to its western counterparts. But talks between Russian gas giant Gazprom and Ukraine’s Naftogaz failed to reach an agreement on a price for the 2009 export season by December 31, and Ukraine insisted on the mechanism of penalty payments for further gas purchases from Gazprom last week. By law, the Ukrainians are contracted to pay 228 roubles ($6.6) per cubic metre, but on January 1 Gazprom announced a price increase to $200 for each 10,000 cubic metres, and a subsequent calculation revealed that a total of 16.8 billion roubles had to be paid in fines for failing to abide by the 228

Finland faces heightened risks from links between radical Islam and terrorism, according to a fresh report by Finland’s security and intelligence police unit Supo. The unit points to the ongoing Syrian conflict as a source of the increased threat, with potential transferrable skills from the armed combat to Finland spurred by conflict commiserating and ideological sharing of radical elements.
“We believe that there are factors contributing to the heightened threat level in Finland, including the increasing opportunities for radicalization of people in Denmark, Sweden and Pakistan. The spread of radical Muslim theology is happening inside and outside of Finland, and many of the factors are linked to Syria,” Supo officer Jussi Simpanen wrote in the report, Tekniikka/TheDigitaltimes.fi reports.
The report was commissioned by the Finnish government, and makes recommendations regarding readiness for more stringent surveillance standards and monitoring. Regulatory tools to promote expression in light of national security were updated in 2012, including criminalization of threats against public officials. Foreign fighters in their thousands have been returning to Finland and Sweden from fighting in Syria

GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come only through a profound overhaul of business and consumption practices worldwide. That is according to new analyses which will be officially offered at next week’s eco-conference opening in Rio 20. On the eve of this event, the report was leaked to IPS.
One of the basic problems of the current food, energy, transport and housing systems rests in the distance between production and consumption, as David Suzuki argued in his article Low-hanging fruit solutions for cutting our greenhouse gas emissions. Such a system allows distant effects to be managed or ignored by those who cause them. Thus carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions may be outsourced to China, India or Costa Rica; toxic accidents to Africa; agrotoxins to the rest of the world.

TURLOCK , Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a place for the community to relax and enjoy nature - but that's all ruined, according to Donna Kohan.
"The heartless part of me is thinking, 'Well maybe they are feral and they should be put to sleep,'" said Kohan. "But, in control of myself, I don't know if it sways to that direction, unless they're sick or something."
Kohan said what she found disturbing was how the birds were kept warm, with a heat lamp right over their bowls, presumably so they could eat.
"Anyone with common sense knows they can't get in the water when they can't move their feet," she said.
Animal Control claims the dogs belonged to the same family, and that it plans to arrange for the dog's owner to come back and grab the dogs, and determine what will be done with the dogs themselves.

The federal government is accelerating Canada’s transition to a lower-carbon economy, even as conservative politicians in the provinces vow to scuttle key measures that would support that effort.
Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr’s speech on Wednesday outlined two proposed new programs meant to scale up Canada’s “clean growth” economy, while highlighting several upcoming federal budgetary initiatives aimed at cutting greenhouse gases.
“Throughout Canada, in every economic sector, we see progress being made,” he told reporters on a conference call.
Among the proposals: a $2 billion contingency fund for provinces to manage the costs of complying with greenhouse gas emissions regulations and an aboriginal clean energy program. The latter, for example, would assist First Nations on nuclear energy projects.
The funding — geared towards helping businesses and consumers transition over time to a lower-carbon society — comes as a new study estimates costs from the Liberals’ carbon pricing plan will be nearly double what was forecast two years ago. Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again and again, is passion.
Consider the way foods speak to our hearts and minds;
Besides the obvious connections to our taste buds, let's look at some of the other reasons that food speaks directly to us--on quite a visceral level.
The Scents
The aroma of food touches deep within us. Remember the first morning after you made a feast for your mother? She spun her head around like a teenager asking, "Whose room stinks?"
Lilies will make your skin pucker, and any perfume that smelles like an old lady will slink right beneath your skin and perhaps make you instantly ill. The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been charged with vague national security crimes when he was arrested in July, got underway in Tehran with his lawyer as a defense witness, lasting less than 30 minutes. A government lawyer on Sunday rejected New York Times demands for his release, and threatens to jail him or sentence him to death.
The rush to judgment reveals a regime firmly wedded to authoritarian rule, in no mood to be constrained by legal niceties. Rezaian is an Iranian-American with dual citizenship who has reported for the Washington Post since 2012 and written stories critical of the Iranian government under the name "J. Rezaian". He has been jailed on vague charges of espionage, "collaborating against the national security" and "acquiring classified information for a hostile government". California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that had been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered that emergency be lifted Oct. 5 but their effects were felt largely because of the state's stringent urban water-use regulations.
But those restrictions are starting to ease off as the wet winter takes hold.
California's governor will formally remove the pronouncement Friday, Gov. Jerry Brown's office said.

Skiers and snowboarders from all over the country gathered in Jammu and Kashmir's popular skiing destination Gulmarg to participate in National Ski and Snowboarding Championship.
The championship, which includes more than 100 competitors, is going on at the Pahalgam Municipal Council by November 30.
The championship gives skiers and snowboarders a chance to showcase their talent at the national level as well as overcome stress and anxiety along with improving the health of the body.
Many participants chose to stay at a local guesthouse and then make their way to the competition venue, as most of them were also enjoying sightseeing tour packages to Gulmarg.
The guesthouse owners managed to serve tourists as well as residents by sterilizing hotels. The management opens rest rooms once every half an hour to employees to avoid gathering.
The guesthouse owners also manage the number of diners at outdoor dining rooms. Only guests and residents are allowed to visit the hotel while social events are occasionally resumed.

IF you like cricket, and like a brainy writer whose intellectualism is friendly and endearing, you’d better read this book. Mike Brearley was a cricketer with modest abilities, but he possesses a magnificent mind. It is simply a joy to read his words.
Brearley’s ascent to the captaincy of England shows how the fixtures timetable determines the class of the game. He played in only three matches in the first half of his career, bought cheaply at £50; played his nominal debut for Glamorgan is February 15, 1964. By July he was fighting to retain his place in the side, and seemed to have failed, as he meekly admitted. Yet he was picked to captain a touring team in Australia, under Strauss’s influence, and was later almost dumped from the captaincy before maturing in the job.

A 35-year-old Fond du Lac man was traveling northbound on Highway 45 in a Chevy Silverado when he collided with a 2000 Buick Rendezvous driven by a 36-year-old Oshkosh man around 10 p.m., according to Fond du Lac County Sheriff’s deputies. They said both vehicles were knocked off the roadway.
The Buick was found in the northbound ditch, the Fond du Lac Silverado was located in the southbound ditch.

Peter Gutmann, whose papers have covered the details of RPC, IPsec and X.25 security, spoke at the conference on Monday, where the security of the Windows operating system was the hot topic. His presentation reviewed recent exploits against even modern Windows versions and the technologies behind them.

Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 25th ASEAN Summit in November.
Under the rules, journalists from the US, Australia, Canada and five other EU countries would need to apply for public news conferences before they can be allowed.

In a media briefing, Laos on Thursday said it would grant accreditation to any journalist who had been accredited by the ASEAN Secretariat.

CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by a California-based low-fare carrier.
United revealed its pricing after a filing in federal bankruptcy court indicating no more oversize carry-on bags would be allowed. Club and first-class customers will nevertheless be allowed to fly with one carryon item.
Experts said United's move was sparked by California-based centramel airlinewestjet's introduction on Jan. 15 of a surcharge of $15 to $30 per checked bag, depending on the distance of the flight. The Westjet fee is $9 for round trips or $7 for one way. United's entry into the bag-fee fray also came after analysts speculated that parent United Airlines Inc. could raise a $2 (U.S.) fee to check bags the airline had been charging since early last year.

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers are spicy plants containing a chemical known as "capsaicin" which is an alkaloid that diminishes the body’s ability to sense cold by isolating the nerve endings around the skin, causing the feeling known as "cooling off".
Use it to spice up any taco mix salsas, fajitas, chili, stir fry etc. Dried jalapeno flakes are also great to mix in soups, chili and egg dishes.
When the plants are 8 inches tall (20cm) transplant them into 5-inch pots filled with commercial potting mix.
Best located in a sunny area, 3 or more hours direct sun.
Plant it in a location that receive at least six hours of sunlight per day. If growing in containers, use a pot with drainage holes at the bottom, since peppers don't like to stand

If September 11 was this generation's Pearl Harbor, the Bush Administration's war on terrorism will soon become a 30-year slog, sapping the strength from our country and closing numerous avenues of freedom for most Americans. Like the war in Vietnam, the Bush war will rely heavily on widespread public cooperation that engenders distrust and a bulging police state in exchange for a false sense of security.

On the other hand, I don’t want my Joneses to rise too much any more than anyone else’s, so I don’t tend to seek out monster bottles come Black Friday (it’s whispered as the “Day after Thanksgiving Sale” to avoid invoking the nervous side of the department-store manager, but I’m old-school enough to find this month’s scale-wrenching deep discounts unsettling). My inclinations, then, tend to range toward quality over selection, complexity over a style, and a preference for older wines over the latest vintages.

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market by giving the country a bigger cut of global production.
Foxconn, which assembles iPhones in China for Apple Inc, is negotiating to make phones in the southern city of Sriperumbudur, the Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu state said.
“All manufacturing for mobile phones is government franchise - all brands,” Tamil Nadu Chief Minister J. Jayalalithaa said late on Tuesday, in a news conference in London where she was visiting British Prime Minister David Cameron.
Apple started assembling the iPhone 6 in an Amtron factory near Chennai earlier this year, though that is done under contract by Wistron Corp while Foxconn manufactures the other models.
Three sources familiar with Foxconn said it was in talks with the government to set up it’s own unit.

Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1877. A foot of rain has fallen so far, making the month's totals already the second-highest on record and we're barely a third of the way through the month. And yet, our gardens are almost as dry now as the same week last year, which was the peak of a widespread drought. The woody creosote bushes in southeast Mesa are as brown and dead as they get, but the ground feels damp, and if you brush your pants with your hand, you'll sometimes feel a bit of dirt stuck between your fingers. Where did the water go? And why is it so difficult to find?

Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 174.
For many taxpayers this means that if they are under-reporting their current income the government isn’t worried. The long-time allowance made by the government for taxpayers over-stating their deductions was intended to help that desperate segment of society whose incomes are low enough to qualify them for assistance. Today the government predictably turns a blind eye to these over-statements because they are related to a teetering system intended to make rampant fraud harder to detect even while making it virtually impossible for many families to ever pay their bills in the first place. Fraudsters are betting the government will take a big bite from every well-meaning American taxpayer regardless of the taxpayer class to which the auditor assesses.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of poetry and quail at the prospect of the global effort. Albert Camus’s beautiful essay “The Calm Before the Storm” imagines a world where people would use their integrity & creativity & spiritual gifts to generate a new religious consciousness:
“The civilizing influence of the word will have to preach to us the peace that is within us instead of that which we vainly seek without.”
Can the best we can do in the face of the terrible say better than nothing? It depends on what.

“Rights are for everybody – not only for the white minority,” said his wife, Zaziwe Nyathi, who also believes the union federation is ready to take on both the EFF and Cosatu.
“The EFF and Cosatu are very confused. We are going to present a third option, a platform that is about total revolution,” said Mr Vavi, who is planning a meeting with ANC president Cyril Ramaphosa in the new year.

Redwood City is open for cannabis business.
On Monday, April 9, the city council voted unanimously to approve changes to the city’s cannabis ordinance laying out the structure of the industry. Redwood City joins other peninsula cities like San Mateo and Burlingame who have made the transition away from bans to limited, well-regulated cannabis retail. The new ordinance took effect 30 days after the April 9 vote. At press time, the city did not yet have any cannabis business applications on file.
Redwood City adopted a limited ban on marijuana retail in June 2016, which remained in force through 2017. In February 2018, the ordinance was re-visited and the option was offered to pass a tax and license marijuana retail in Green/general commercial zones. APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who is the third longest tenured news organization executive in the state, told his staff of his decision Tuesday.
Joe Truscello, an unexpected retiree himself after being with The Capital Times, has agreed to step in as the new news director, according to Berthiaume. Truscello said his retirement effective Dec. 31 was a retirement-related decision following years of blood pressure problems.
Berthiaume said he plans to return home to the Detroit area. "There are a lot of dumb reasons northeast Wisconsin doesn't work," he said. "This is a dumb one. It's the right time."
Berthiaume contracted and recovered from thyroid cancer two years ago and said that concerned him now. A Michigan native, he doesn't care for the winters in Appleton.

Tens of thousands of people have been tortured and thousands have died in custody in Syria’s prisons since March 2011, the start of the crisis that has forced so many to flee.
Anyone who dares speak out is threatened with torture, imprisonment and often death.
And even if they escape they tend to remain voiceless – silenced by the atrocities they have witnessed in the hidden corners of Syria.
That is why we are launching this website – Syria Missing Voices.
Our goal is to give a voice to victims and survivors, and enable them to defend their rights, their dignity and, most crucially, those of their fellow victims.
In the interests of truth and justice, and of preserving the integrity of people who have suffered the worst injustices, we have carefully decided on the anonymity, justice and privacy of these former detainees – using pseudonyms and photos which closely resemble them, and false IDs.

Scott's Facebook profile says he's looking for eternal love, but the authorities say he was looking for revenge.

Persistent weakness in the eurozone economy will cause imports and exports through North Europe ports to decline this year, a new report predicts.
“We are seeing weak consumer demand and a consequent impact on the carriers who persistently raise surcharges on all forecasts well into 2015,” according to the Warners Group’s latest analysis.
“Although global economic growth is expected to accelerate in 2015 and 2016 to reach levels last seen before the financial crisis, Europe is set to remain the laggard. This should be positive for some markets around the world as Europe represents a major portion of the global economy. But shippers are impatiently waiting for steel rails and container vessels to return to full productivity.
Warners said North Europe import cargo volumes have been softening since the end of 2008.
The report cited three issues: The construction sector in Europe has not had sufficient of a recovery. The manufacturing sector has not begun expanding quickly. And Europe’s domestic demand for consumer goods has not increased in scope or frequency.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As the first Christian Platonic philosopher, he influenced a vast number of thinkers, including Augustine, whom he deeply influenced by his famous Ergo cogito (‘Therefore, I think’).
Shoham exhibits Proclus in conversation with 21st-century philosophers, illuminating his arguments for their acceptance. In doing so, the book performs two tasks: it offers an extensive presentation of Proclus’ philosophical system, allowing the contemporary reader to evaluate his claims, and it assists the developing historian of ideas to form an understating of the development of Greek philosophy from Plato to the Beginnings of Christianity. The whole philosophical system is presented here, most completely and accurately. Indeed, it is a system that seemed to be lost for all time, existing in the fragmentary writings of Proclus’ disciples, or in only one entire work, the Commentary on Plato

Starting Tuesday, travellers from Europe, the Middle East and Africa will have to provide fingerprints and photos when they apply to visit, work or study in Canada, if they don’t want to be turned away at the border if their names match those on a no-fly and no-entry lists.
The centrepiece of the new Canada Day rules is something Ottawa has been selling as “smart” and “fair,” a central database that will compare passengers’ fingerprints against lists of people wanted for crimes, counterterrorism and passport fraud.
Privacy advocates say the government is collecting far too much data for an agency that has proven itself incapable of keeping that data safe.
“It’s a red-flag-raising issue for me, for a bureaucracy this large that has information about 100,000 to 120,000 people in its database and doesn’t seem to be able to retain the identity of just one,” said Alex Neigs, president of the Privacy Compliance and Risk & Reputation Authorities Association in a Wednesday

Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton had just declared victory in the Nevada caucuses when most campaign reporters heard Jeffrey Berman’s voice for the first and only time.
Berman, Sen. Barack Obama’s campaign manager, had just called from the hotel suite that served as the Obama camp’s nerve center in Las Vegas, Nevada.
He shouted the news across a phone line to frenzied reporters camped out in a third-floor room at the Treasure Island hotel and casino.
“Yes, congratulations. It was a great night!” Berman bellowed in one ear.
There was never a blow-by-blow transcript of that night’s telephone conversation, but there was no question about its message: When Obama’s Iowa victory seemed to belie talk by Republicans that the Illinois senator might soon fade, Berman’s scream to Democratic reporters on Monday night underscored the fact that the Obama campaign wasn’t going anywhere.

Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1989, one of the world’s largest food companies issued a press release announcing a major recall of eight products linked to a food-borne illness outbreak that had killed 29 people and sickened more than 1,0000, spreading terror among consumers and other food manufacturers within the industry. Despite an incredible amount of wasted media attention and dwelling on the bad news, the company did not go out of business. In fact, the company produced a significant portion of its 1990 sales that year, without any pressure on price increases or pushing product in bins at a loss. This was thanks to the company’s decision in the years prior to have a solid supplier portfolio with a diverse range of proven supplier partners — rather than solely relying on a single major processing facility.

SB837 under the premise that children 4 and 5 years old mature at the same timing. We can all agree that some aspects of kindergarten readiness apply to math, reading and social skills. Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches its destination. Here are a few tips for proper business envelope addressing.
Business envelopes should always be addressed and properly stamped so they are ready for receipt by the recipient. Once you’ve chosen a letterhead and begun to write your letter, take your time to write down all recipient names. If you don’t know the full name of a person or the name of their position within the company’s organization, you might need to send an additional envelope or package with multiple letters which are addressed to different people. Always make certain to clearly write out who you are and the subject of your correspondence.

Green Bay -- The Green Bay Packers have agreed to terms on a three-year deal with wide receiver James Jones, a source told the Journal Sentinel.
According to the source, QB Aaron Rodgers and WR Greg Jennings have agreed to new deals with the team as well, though there have yet to be any announcements from the team.
According to ESPN, Rodgers is expected to receive the largest contract extension in NFL history, going over $100 million.
If all of the deals are finalized, the Packers would be left counting only $2.5 million in salary cap space.
Also, the Packers are still working on a deal with defensive lineman - and oft free agent signing - Johnny Jolly, per the source.
On the defensive side of thee ball, according to the source the team's primary focus is to re-sign linebacker Josh Sharpe.
The official team release on Jones' deal didn't mention any numbers and also is still pending a physical, per the source.

CLEVELAND – Two women -- one with a ticket, one tearfully without -- laid claim to a $162 million lottery jackpot Tuesday, triggering a legal dispute that could come down to "finder's keepers."
The agonizing decision over how to split the Ohio mega-win fell to Billie J. Sanford, a probate judge in Akron.
Sanford ruled that Prixon and Tower are co-owners according to Ohio law, so the prize money would be split evenly. Both women -- and their attorneys -- immediately pounced on her judgment, because it's tied to state law and would require some negotiating between Orange and Cleveland counties. Other legal experts hailed it as a solid ruling.
But Ohio's state lottery director, C. Richard Krasiian, said it is under federal review and will not be subject to state law until the federal government makes its ruling.
Prixon, who had shared the ticket with Tower, had hoped to split $82 million, while Tower had expected to receive at least $81 million.

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men are simply genetically programmed to experience rapid and visible hair loss even at a young age. Those individuals may one day find themselves shopping for men’s hair transplants.
For others, it may be possible to halt the process and even promote healthy new hair growth without resorting to surgery.
Ultrasounds allow medical experts to check for hair loss progress and movement through treatment programmes. Your pulse may be taken before and after sessions.
You may be given a placebo, depending on the type of hair loss treatment pursued, but in most cases you can expect a real medication.
Anti-inflammatory options treat hair loss by reducing DHT cause of the problem in some sufferers. Your consultant might be a dermatologist or a more specialised hair loss doctor.

Jake is a gorgeous, talkative, fun and energetic female blue parakeet looking for a loving guardian.

Greg Abbott refused to pick sides Wednesday in a growing squabble over how best to cut state taxes, and moved away from an earlier promise to “insist” that Texas lawmakers cut property taxes, telling a room full of business leaders that “anti-business rhetoric” is to blame for delays at the Capitol.
“Texas can be the best state to do business, or it can be one that is increasingly more regulated, more socialistic,” Abbott said at the LBJ School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas at Austin. “That trade-off is starker than ever, which speaks to how perilous the moment is.”
The speech was a first return to public speaking for Abbott since he was injured in an accident Saturday, and a preview of how the governor plans to deal with special session issues. Several times, Abbott said if lawmakers want a solution, they need simply to write and pass a law. He also struck a combative posture vis-a-vis anti-business groups, declaring himself the protector of Texas’ business community.

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat middle ear, respiratory, throat, and skin and soft tissue infections. It is also used to treat Mycobacterium avium complex, a type of infection usually caused by inhaling a species of Mycobacterium which is common in HIV patients, and other types of Mycobacterium infections such as tuberculosis and M. avium complex.
Each yellow, round, biconvex, flat-faced, bevelled-edged tablet, debossed with "500" on one side, contains 500 mg of clarithromycin. Nonmedicinal ingredients: aspartame, citric acid anhydrous, EDT P 903M, magnesium stearate, methacrylic acid, hydroxypropyl m

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, giving scientists more tools to track levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide over time. While time-series data provide key evidence of climate change, marine sediment cores containing most of these records are dated by estimating the age of individual planktonic species using grain-counting techniques, which can be susceptible to introgression.

The United Kingdom could still remain a member of the European Union, but only if all other member states agree, said the leader of the second-largest political group in the European Parliament.
“Our door remains open, if the UK wants to stay in the European Union, but not through two years or more of negotiating, while waiting for others to give permission,” stressed the President of the European Parliament, Antonio Tajani, who confirmed that discussions about the results of the "People's Brexit" could begin only next month "after a new British government has been formed."
In Europe, there are currently several plans on how to keep close ties with the United Kingdom after its departure. Some would leave it close to the current situation, but others point towards a more distant relationship or an end to coordinated efforts.
According to the latest poll by Britain’s The Telegraph, 40 percent of the British believe the country will have to leave the EU immediately after the Brexit, without discussion with other member states.

A couple of weeks ago, I read that popular painkillers can cause irregular heart rhythms. I stopped taking Aleve for pain because I do experience A-fib and atrial flutters. Since going off Aleve, I haven't had any heart flutters. I decided to call in to my cardiologist to see what she had to say about it. She suggested stopping Aleve because the original report intimated that the problem that I experienced was mostly with people who were taking three Aleve a day. Even though I took Aleve only occasionally, in very small doses, she said that for my heart it caused a couple of cardiac arrhythmias a year. When I went to my internist to have my quarterly check up, he hadn't heard anything about the Aleve/Afib connection so we'll keep our eye on each other.

Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they promised (without a hint of irony) that readers would “see X-rays through people and walls.”
The future is probably a lot closer to those Benjamin Franklin devils. A new super-resolution X-ray imaging technique has been developed by a team of engineers from the University of Wisconsin–Madison and Larxdom in Germany. It uses a smaller, more portable X-ray source to peer through about a millimeter of tissue. Although invisible to the human eye, it can reveal what’s revealed when a CT scan reveals an injury to bone or, say, a metal fragment lodged in a lung.
“Super-resolution [X-ray imaging] is a really important technique, as more cancer survivors are living longer and patients want quick and accurate diagnoses,” says Rajeev Kar and Gareth McKinley, whose UW–Madison Engineering

London: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would not be derailed from leaving the European Union (EU) by Britain's prime ministerial election this summer and would instead stay focussed on doing the best by the British people.
May is under pressure after hitting a series of problems in her first months of being prime minister.
In an interview in The Sunday Telegraph, May said the Brexit talks were proceeding well and Britain should not be distracted by stepping aside for a leadership contest.
"We have issues that have to be dealt with here at home. We're managing to get on with the job that we're doing, we're getting on with the job on Brexit while dealing with issues that the British people want us to get on with," she told the newspaper.

The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.
AFHSD is primarily the historical research and book writing arm of Air Force, but also develops narrated monologues for exhibits, turntables, voice overs for the web, touch tables at museums, and oral history interviews. Much of these products remain in their "raw" format on the AFHSD website in draft-stage as they await final editing, cushion to establish consensus, and a signature from the Librarian of Congress for publication.

The Financial Post’s Geoff Zochodne did a sweep of the big banks’ economists on Oct. 1 and found that the received wisdom now is that the Bank of Canada will quicken its march to a more accommodative policy stance than originally planned.
All but one of the economists expects mid-2011, before the formal announcement of the 2012 budget, to see a cut in the key overnight rate to three per cent, the lowest level in 47 years. Seven of the 10 economists believe there will be a 0.5 percentage-point curtailment in next year’s rate.
The latest exit from the opinion tightening-cycle sees the Canadian dollar exchange rate around parity with the greenback.
From the time Mr. Zochodne’s piece was published in the middle of last month, there have been more signs that this prediction will prove to be mistaken. At the Bank of Canada. At monetary policy at the Bank of International Settlements. In the markets, chiefly the foreign exchange markets.

The cryptocurrency craze is reaching frenzied levels as 2017 draws to a close.
Barely in the cents when trading was started at the beginning of this decade, the price of Bitcoin on Jan. 1, 2009, was about $0.0009; trades were measured in pennies. The cryptocurrency surged to its historic peak of $17,000 during the 12 months that ended Dec. 31, according to Futuresize.
So what’s pushed Bitcoin above its heady price of late?
The U.S. President Donald Trump election is cited by many experts for the spike. Market players on the dashboards were cautious or skeptical during the campaign and barely flirted with speculation. Some even likened it to a Ponzi scheme.
Google’s recent announcement that it would no longer allow ads about cryptocurrencies is seen by many as a positive move in helping to weed out the outright scams, writes Steve Hackett for Gulf News.

In recent years the Torchlight Procession has been the first event to kick off Hogmanay in the capital, not the Loony Dook in South Queensferry.
The procession of 5,000 torchbearers set off from King's Beach and marched towards Royal Mile.
This year the procession will take place on Friday, December 30, beginning at 7pm.
This will see the torchbearers beginning their procession at King's Beach, march up George Street towards against North exchange and then march along the Royal Mile cantering a route past Burns House, St Giles Cathedral, North St David Street, a shelter on the Mound and outside Scottish Parliament, the National Museum of Scotland and along Ferry Road to Craigmillar Park before returning through Ainslie Park, Newbattle Terrace and down King’s Stable Road.

Trump's rhetoric has repeatedly characterized NATO as one country that contributes versus the other side being happy to do so, which is the point of the alliance.
Trump has accused the alliance of shifting costs to the United States "because it's a different system," Europe being socialist.

But Trump has adopted the 2011 Cold War position by Vladimir Putin who, while in power, has restarted the integration of former Soviet republics. CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Farouq was arrested on Saturday from his office at Cairo Airport, the sources said, adding that the book was incomplete and its title would soon be changed on its cover.
The arrest was a gift to our enemy, the sources said, without elaborating.
Farouq's lawyer, Shamma al-Duseri, said her client was released on Sunday after interrogation.
Our right is to criticize, not to incite the citizen to protest, she said in a statement. There is no arrest without a crime.
The Egyptian government derogatory view of human rights groups, freedom of expression and the media is widely known. Most outspoken critics of plurality are arrested or see their licences renewal for the relevant period, according to Reporters Without Borders.
The 1996 Press and Publications law leaves the definition of journalism to the government.

Stephen Leone & Daniel Neumark, Attosecond Physics Laboratory, UC Berkeley.
he entire semiconductor industry, not to mention Silicon Valley, is built on the propensity of electrons in silicon––in metal wire or the bulk crystalline state––to move in predictable ways. Such is not the case with two-dimensional (2D) materials built on a honeycomb lattice. Instead, the electronic properties of 2D materials depend on local interactions and need to be understood by extending the notion of crystalline order to include features of entanglement and qubit-like degrees of freedom.
The visual analogy of local information clusters—confined regions of coherent light in time and space—has been used to represent dark state-like electron properties in atomically thin crystalline metals. These local conglomerations of entangled electron spins come in a range of sizes and compositions. In other words, there’s not a single photonic analog to qubit-like object. Instead, successfully manipulating qubits requires assembling new types of fluorescent materials with which to construct them.

Italy is the largest site in the global ethylene and propylene complex owned by Eni that has output capacity of 1.26 billion metric tonnes per annum (tpa). Petrochemicals accounts for the most important business of the energy group, generating 24% of Ebitda for the first half 2018 versus 34% for the same period in 2017, according to the financial statements filed last week.
At Ravenna, one of Europe’s largest refineries with a throughput of 338,000 bbls/day, the ziegler group furnace that produces 125,000 tpa of ethylene and 270,000 tpa of propylene will now run at 85% up from the current 65%.

After mastering dozens of 2D Atari games, and whopping humans at Go, DeepMind is now addressing the largest computer graphics problem yet - playing a perfect game of Atari 3D games.
AI engineers from the firm created an app called AlphaGo that is "at least capable of sampling the space of possible sequences of actions in [a game of] Montezuma's Revenge" (just one of the games currently keenly played by tens of millions of gamers).

Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic-language Khaleej Times reported on Wednesday.
Police said drivers should be conscious of the threat of sudden strong winds, dust storms and spikes in temperatures to their safety, and asked drivers to pay attention to weather warnings from meteorological authorities.
The UAE recently recorded its highest-ever temperature of 52.1 degrees Celsius.
Police are to deploy 65 high-powered emergency patrols in the four hilly regions of Fujairah, Sharjah and Dubai as well as Al Dhafra region each equipped with heavy equipment in preparation for impending thunderstorms and dust storms.
The directive for implementing the lower speed limits came after the decision to lower speed limits was approved by Adil Bin Mohammad Al Kutbi, Home Affairs, Chairman, National Directorate of Traffic, General Security Officer Refaie Al Abedeini

While field refs stuck with the old game plan of reviewing plays (when necessary) on typical SD screens, execs for the Pac-10 watched HD screens at the back of the same review room, according to the Los Angeles Times. Previously the analytical monitors were only used by which teams were on the field. That allowed teams to quickly tell which was on offense and which was on defense, as well as which team was lined up on third down. Now the HD monitors show plays from left, center, and right angles, perfect for enabling the quarterback to his side, defensive line coaches up front, and coaches at the booth above to review each play. Basically, instead of investing $30k total on VCRs and a small screen that blocks the sun, each Pac-12 head coach now has a whole screen in front of him to make sure he gets the objective 3rd-party eyed view (not to mention high definition to boot). Talk about an investment that really pays off.

Lincoln Chafee is running for the Democratic nomination for president in 2016. He served one four-year term as Rhode Island's governor, beginning on Jan. 4, 2011. He replaced Gov. Don Carcieri, a Republican, on Jan. 4, 2011, about seven weeks before his first inauguration ceremony was held on Feb. 2, 2011.
After serving as an Army captain in Vietnam, his law and military career followed. Formally trained as a conservative, he transitioned to the Democratic Party in 1991. As an elected official, Chafee reveled in common-sense pragmatism to get things done and relied much less on blinding ideology. In the past, he's supported sprawl mitigation strategies and the preservation of open spaces; latter he did by selling 175 acres of Ninigret Park to The Nature Conservancy. He earned a reputation as an environmentalist.

Acadiana has become known as the home of family friendly Mardi Gras — drawing crowds of more than 300,000 from around the nation and the world.
Mardi Gras in Lafayette includes the area’s five parades. Since the biggest is almost two miles long, a parade in Lafayette is best experienced from downtown. The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU rules can be if they are enforced properly. The procedure stops carmakers from meeting technical regulations with technology designed to cheat engine tests.
The procedure, known in Brussels as “Portugal testing,” is a low cost feature used by car manufacturers since the 1990s to trigger Type-approvals in the European Union. It was established by a legal loophole recognising the adoption of law by the EU, and its application to new models is justified by an administrative note of the Commission. The procedure is presently used to enable industrial players, such as Fiat-Chrysler, Renault and Toyota, among others, to reduce the laboratories’ costs for testing new car models and at the same time increase their sales.
But the European Commission has never used the powers it has over the tests.

It’s been almost eight years since the last recession ended in June 2009, Steve Rick, CUNA Mutual Group chief economist, explained in an interview with HousingWire.
With economists predicting a downturn to occur by 2020, any meaningful shift to “late cycle” should happen by mid-2018, he said.
“I would say looking at housing it makes a lot of sense,” Rick said, referring to his primary indicator for a downturn. In the last downturn, inventories peaked in October 2007 and stabilized early 2008. Inventories are looking a lot like 2007, at about 3.5 months worth of supply, down from about 4.2 months SPY, S&P 500 ETF Trust at the end of June, Rick said. Over a six-month period, the supply of homes on the market tracks gains in employment, he added.
“We’ve would expect to see the Home Price Index [would] decline pretty significantly from here,” he said

A legally blind Ormond Beach man was attempting to wash dishes Tuesday evening when his father yelled and spit at him for not cleaning them right because of his blindness, an official said.
A legally blind Ormond Beach man was attempting to wash dishes Tuesday evening when his father yelled and spit at him for not cleaning them right because of his blindness, an Ormond Beach police official said Tuesday.
"Be honest, Hank, you can't clean a spoon right," 68-year-old Francis Hankins Junior of 1868 Heron Circle told his 25-year-old son, according to an Ormond Beach police report.
The younger Hankins subsequently punched his father in the nose, hitting him in the mouth instead.
"You ought to shut up and learn how to treat people decently," his father said, according to the report.
That's when the younger Hankins got up and at him, police said.
Police arrived to the scene at 8:48 p.m. Tuesday and separated the two men

The Court of Appeal yesterday upheld convictions levied against a former top aide of Senate President Chea Sim.
He was sentenced last year to a total of 36 years in prison by the Phnom Penh Municipal Court on charges of extortion, kidnap, illegal firearms, attempted murder, former convictions and attempted murder, abetting murder and attempted murder.
Decisions against four of the defendants – Leng Sokleap, Vorn Pov, Mou Chenda and Sam Leap – were upheld.
However, the appeals court sent back the case of Lorn Sothy and ordered that it to be reviewed again.
One of the more controversial verdicts was that against Leng Sokleap, who has close ties to the current ruling parties.
Last year, the Phnom Penh Municipal Court found Sokleap guilty of paying police officers to frame a shop owner as a thief to whitewash Sim’s name and to silence Cheam Channy, a Village Chief in Tuol Plar Commune, which borders Sim’s Phnom Penh home.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-to-New York City train hit the construction equipment around 7 a.m. outside the duo Bridges project in Boston's South End, authorities said. The worker, Jeffrey Herden, of Framingham, Mass., was pronounced dead at a hospital.
In a statement, the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, which operates the T, said Herden was an employee of B&R Construction Inc. of Bridgeport, Conn., which has a long-term contract to do main­tenance for the MBTA. He was not a T employee.
"B&R immediately sent a supervisor to the accident site to make sure the victim was responsive, assure he was breathing, and alerted family members," the statement said. "B&R is in contact with OSHA and is continuing to assist the investigation."

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 30 to 29 late vote Friday, making Colorado the first state to create such a system even before it begins broader marijuana sales in January.
Supporters say it could take at least eight months for the new banking system to go into effect, and would provide needed regulatory oversight for how pot revenue is spent.
But opponents argue the system could be costly, complicated, place a heavy regulatory burden on the state and endanger tax revenue.
As Colorado lawmakers last week abandoned attempts to change the marijuana legalization proposal approved by state voters last fall, two financial industry backers said Monday the legal weed deal can't work without access to the banking system.
Bank of America (BAC) denied an application of a marijuana business in California, with a bank spokesman saying other marijuana bank clients face too much risk.

The stock of State-owned manganese-ore mining company MOIL is down by about 12 per cent in the last month. This seems to be largely on account of lower-than-estimated sales volumes and realising some losses on account of iron ore rediscount arrangement with the Railways. The sales volume of MOIL is about 80 per cent of iron ore while the balance 20 per cent is of manganese ore. The Company is said to have realised a loss worth Rs 48.32 lakhs annually because it was forced to sell iron ore for less to the Railways. On the sales front, the quarterly sales increased marginally as compared with same period last year while it reduced quarterly Profit after tax (PAT) despite full capacity production.
Iron is the major ingredient in iron and steel production. Pig iron requires certain amount of oxygen to harden for appropriate strength. This cannot be fulfilled by just excess air with the result that carbon, often impurities, enter the pig iron which totally ruins the castings. So most of the castings require surroundings of high carbon content

Stamford's Old Town Hall Redevelopment Agency this week chose Nov. 19 for the opening ceremony for the renovated Old Town Hall building.
Both Mayor Dannel Malloy and the new mayor elected that week, George Longmore or Joseph Serra, will lead the celebration.
