It is a nightmare scenario hospitals must be prepared for, although they hope those preparations will never be used.
On Monday, that nightmare came to Kingston General Hospital when the sound of gunshots shattered the relative calm as the hospital successfully went to lockdown.
It was a verbal argument that spread into the hospital. One of the people involved refused care.
Durham police spotted the man, who had a warrant out for his arrest. They called for back-up.
Eventually, three ― including one with a rifle ― entered the hospital ward and engaged in a physical confrontation with the man.
Several shots were fired. The man was taken to hospital with a gunshot wound elsewhere, but still alive.
An ambulance had just pulled in to the emergency bay at KGH around the time of the shooting. Paramedics helped move the patients about from one room to another in the same event. The arrested man was hit by one of the bullets a short distance away.
Police said he faces charges.

The final group of Irish peacekeepers to serve in Chad arrived back in Dublin this afternoon.
For the first time in three decades, there are now no large Irish battalions serving overseas.
The 180 members of the touring ‘Dublin’ Battalion’ were greeted on a flight from Chad at Dublin Airport.
They have been deployed in the country for almost six months, where they were protecting humanitarian corridors.
The deployment was part of United Nations mission alongside around 26,000 other peacekeepers.
On arrival, they spoke to state broadcaster RTÉ about their return home.

Slowing economic growth in China is taking some of the glow off of one of the country’s greatest attractions for foreign businesses: consumers’ willingness to splurge on higher-priced goods as incomes rise. In India, economic factors like inflation, high household debt loads and sluggish bank credit are jeopardizing consumers’ appetites for high-end goods.
For a decade since the worldwide financial crisis, China was the darling of U.S. companies looking for the next big thing. Rising incomes from an ascending middle class were fuelling the market for costlier generics, electronics, consumer durables and food.
India — by some accounts the world’s next-most populous nation after China — had investors’ imagination fired by the shared belief that its demographic makeup favoured the growth of a rapidly expanding middle class. But as global economic growth slows and trade protectionism rises, the strong tail winds of increasing growth and rising consumption that countries like India and China were basking in have begun to slow to a stiff breeze of anxiety.

On June 17, hundreds of thousands of Dominicans of Haitian descent will be stateless.
Last week, I wrote that the Dominican Republic has summarily stripped over a hundred thousand Dominicans born in the DR of Dominican nationality. The DR’s Constitution stipulates that foreign born descendants of slaves who attain Dominican citizenship are able to pass down their Dominican citizenship to their children. But in 2008 the Dominican DR amended its Constitution, specifically barring children born of illegal migrants from automatically inheriting Dominican nationality unless they can prove permanent residency and labor registration certificates. These certificates are require only for legal migrant workers (including migrants who over-stay their tourist visas to work illegally). Children born of illegally migrant mothers are thus stripped of their Dominican nationality through no fault of their own, not even being aware that they are not Dominicans despite being raised in the Dominican Republic.

When it comes to corruption and Congress, the line the law polices is the wrong line, writes Lawrence Lessig.
Seven years after moving from the federal capital to a federal prison, former congressman (and top gun Navy pilot) Randy "Duke" Cunningham has earned himself an escape from the Rahm Emanuel approach to prosecuting those policing the last election. On Wednesday, federal Judge Larry Burns overturned the conviction on those grounds. And it'd be difficult to find a better example of how cynical the entire process of enforcing campaign-finance law has become.
Popularism says that legislators should be punished for enriching themselves by enacting policies that enrich themselves and others. Wrong. Anyone selling access to the power of legislation has a different swift within the body of his or her respective institution. Nearly 50 years of protests, lawsuits and ballot battles over low-income housing have made San Francisco a nationwide model for efforts to keep urban America from becoming home to only the very rich or the very poor.
The results of the Nov. 7 ballot issue highlighted one of the biggest challenges: While most San Franciscans believe in affordable housing, maintaining a healthy and vital business economy while making sure many low-income residents can stay. Ultimately this small-city example will tell how America fares in meeting that challenge in bigger, more populous metropolises.

ALBANY, N.Y. — DNA barcoding has exposed some infamous cases of food fraud, like cheap catfish masquerading as New Zealand's famed Ora King salmon. But researchers are increasingly finding that DNA can't give us everything we need to know about what we put into our bodies.

The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his prepared testimony, Powell said GDP growth has rebounded in recent months and the job market is firm.
“Business investment has slowed over the past year, advances in technology and trade policy uncertainties have slowed labor market progress and economywide inflation has remained below the committee’s 1% price stability goal for almost three years. These developments along with risks to the financial system have contributed to subdued inflation pressures,” he said.
On Monday the US Federal Reserve said it expected to raise interest rates four times in 2019.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spille in 1886.
It was found by the crew of a cargo ship in 2003 and returned to the Dutch trader, who was delighted to learn it had survived so well.
Mr Spille was a participant in the Dutch North Sea Elephant Expedition to collect video footage from aboard an elephant. The film was intended to show how to dive without the aid of oxygen tanks. The club meets several times a year at the CWA Hall. One of the objectives of the garden club is to educate members and the community of what makes a great garden and the role that plants have in our lives.
They have many members, though most are senior women, have an aim to promote gardening pride and pleasure, to contribute to the general well being of the community, to spread knowledge about local pot plants, to seek and encourage interest and progress in plant growth, and to maintain affiliation with the GSTC.

U by Uniworld has said its ship, The B, will be moving to central Europe for the 2020 season.
With increasing demand for the region, where sister ship The A also resides, The B will cease sailings in Morocco and replace The A in France, Portugal and Spain.
The current programme launched in April 2018 with The A and ended in December 2019.
From April 2020, The B will “focus on the southern region of Spain and Portugal by providing cruises from Seville to Lisbon, as well as a cruise option between Seville and Bordeaux, France”, U by Uniworld said.
The B, built specifically to appeal to younger generations, will have an “emphasis on luxury amenities, small group exploration and the highest comfort,” Uniworld said.
Uniworld – which owns and operates a large all-inclusive cruise portfolio and the River Cruises division – launched the line in April 2018.
U by Uniworld has been designed to cater to millennials seeking immersive experiences

2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller web hosting allows smaller companies to expand their business by selling server space to other website owners.
Many of the largest and most prestigious web hosts are private corporations that do not sell their web hosting services to resellers. They do, however, offer wholesale reseller accounts to companies who want to develop their own line of hosting services. Reseller hosting has grown in popularity over the years in response to demand for more customizable services at affordable prices.
Another advantage of reseller web hosting is profitability for the host. Certain niches within the internet world seem to prove especially profitable, such as web hosting. After all, server space, network services and storage costs are necessary to keep a website online. Successful reseller web hosting providers can earn a large yearly income in just a few short years.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Fatality Rate, or NFR, is 3.40 deaths per 1,000 live births in 2017 and the Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation benchmark of 1.56 per 1,000 has been reached.
The NFR is the percentage of live babies under 7 days who die from any of the leading causes of childhood disease and includes natural causes in newborns such as alcohol and drug abuse. However, significant disparities still exist across America, where Black mothers have die neonatal death rates four times higher and American Indian mothers nearly two times higher than White mothers. Yet, this is a market worth engaging. For example, more millennials now own homes than at any point within the last 20 years, and the lifelong housing and rental market has matured, as well, expanding to include both corporations and investors.
Increasing access to alternative data is giving new insight into how and why consumers are shopping in the rental market. Through advancements in image recognition, search engine technology and more, potential renters and landlords are entering the rental housing space on informed property views, preferences and faith in career development -- or lack thereof -- based on real estate statistics and trend analyses.

Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy from the Sun. Formed 4.6 billion years ago, the Earth is powered by the fusion reactions that occur at the Sun's core (8.) The nuclear magic called stellar nucleosynthesis results in radioisotopes - protons, neutrons and nuclei - which take on an atomic positively charged nucleus.
Once the stellar nucleosynthesis process ends - 6 billion years ago - heavy elements form. These heavy elements combine into something stable, usually an even heavier element; and are carried out to the atmosphere and ejected in the form of impacts ejecta or absorbed into the mantle. These elements are dispersed in space (9.) Who saidÃ¢â‚¬? the planet is not a family? It is a family but we are still looking for our mom and our source for the family photo. For now, we ignore why Earth nuclear fusion can run a tectonic system.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “mesenchymal stem cells” detected a tumor the microscopic piece of skin 37 times before it could become cancerous. This replication of cells was not found in mice or humans.
Professor Duffy Spring of the University of Buffalo said the elephant’s ability to detect skin cancers in very small clumps of cells shows a quality we may be lacking as humans: A head’s-up ability.
“That mesenchymal stem cell will make copies of itself all in the same place, raising the idea that maybe in humans that cell is spreading more rapidly, instead of being able to figure out a spot of wrongness and move on,” said Spring.
But there is a dark side: The finding could throw elephant biology into disarray.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the University of California—Irvine examined the brains of young adults as they rested in a state of meditation after a 20-minute yoga class. They found that the brain's reward center (known as a dopamine transporter or DAT for short) was more active following a yoga session as compared to when the subjects instead watched a comedy video. This is good news for anyone who's dealt with moderate to severe anxiety or depression. The reward activity is notably lower when a person is not feeling optimal wellbeing.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the dataset known to have been published is from 1553, although there are records of Arctic exploration from as early as the 15th century. The lowest point of the data series comes from 1971. From this point forward, the focus of the data is primarily vessel tracking and professional meteorology, particularly marine ice-driftmeteorological faxback. The dataset is global in coverage. The original data were collected by multiple national meteorological services (US, UK, Norway, Denmark, Germany, etc.) and other institutions, including the Impact Forecasting System, co-sponsored by ACSYS and the Institute for the Study of Earth, Oceans and Space at The University of St. Andrews, Scotland, UK, and the stepwise assimilation model now known as the Naval Research Laboratory Climate and Ocean Assimilation System. "Country Music Hair" author Erin Duvall breaks down the 'dos.
You can't think about country music without thinking about hair. Whenever anyone talks about Dolly Parton, her look is mentioned in the first sentence. You can’t think about the history of country music, or its future, without considering the role of its hair, both high-glossed and dirt-flecked, in making and breaking careers. It’s part of the legend of country, as much as guns and fiddles.
Here are a few changes that have happened over the last 50 years.
Hair and fashion trickled down from pop music into the country market in the early sixties, like things tend to. But since country primarily looks to late-sixties-to-present-day pop as her muses, it’s certainly served only to accelerate and deepen. If you think you can’t discuss country hair without bringing up Hank Thompson, it’s probably a good time to check in on what most was still serving on the plates at that point.

Which Irish names are making a comeback?
For the fifth year in a row, Emily was the most popular female baby name in Ireland in 2015. Emily finished the year ahead of Emma, Ava, Isabella and Aoife in the baby name rankings compiled by the Central Statistics Office.
For the male names, Jack took the top spot followed closely by James, Jake, Oscar and Noah. Jack is also the most common name in the UK.
Both names were in the top ten most popular baby names during the 1980s and 1990s, but are less common today.
The top baby girls names in 2012 and 2013 were Olivia and Sophia. In 2014, it was Isabella, Amelia, Eva and Aoife. This was followed by Olivia and Isabella during 2014.
The top baby boys names over the past six years has been Jack, Oliver, Liam and Harry. Jack also took the top spot during 2014.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter, Halina Karnow, a food writer in England.
His Vietnam War book, “Vietnam: A History,” published in 1983, was the 10th volume of the New York Times Sunday Book Review series “Modern Library: History.” More and more he tended to move away from outright journalism — a pursuit he often credited in interviews for bringing him within earshot of news pulse — leaving him free to think and write with more depth, grounding the analysis in a historical perspective. He became known for his forceful, countering voice, disturbed by the state of modern warfare and conventions, pageantry, celebrity, opacity, dictatorships and political duplicity. Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify which potential choices will provide the best results with minimal risk. The diagram shows the various paths, or outcomes, of the decisions that an employee faces while involved in a business activity.
Devising a decision tree is not simply a question of listing possible outcomes, but is best used when an employee has the information she needs to adequately weigh important facts and considerations. The visual format of the decision tree can be used to describe and highlight central facts, show how certain factors will impact the business and provide pros and cons of each outcome possible under consideration to help professionals choose the best action.
Various business professionals, including senior managers and marketers, may be in charge of creating a decision tree. Large companies or marketers may wish to use an outside consultant when creating such a tool since this type of analysis typically involves large data sets and some interdisciplinary knowledge. Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered down a mountain in Hpakant, in Myanmar's Kachin state, injuring 40 people on Saturday.
Locals rescued 22 workers and pulled six from the mud, police Jackson Mayit, spokesman for the Kachin state police force, told AFP on Sunday.
He said the search was called off because more than 24 hours had elapsed following the landslide.
"So, we relayed the message... to them, asking for them to not to put their lives in danger by searching the wind-blown area as it could cause more landslides," Mayit said.

The 53rd edition of Asia's second biggest film festival honors a total of 17 films this year, including documentaries, short films and animation.

Pat Maloney was a gifted experimental musician in the 1970s, until he suddenly stopped playing entirely.
This story starts with an ending.
Pat Maloney passed away in the late summer of 2018. Outside of a handful of close friends and family, he made no mention that he planned to eventually stop living. Normally when someone dies there’s a period of mourning. A grieving, bereaved party perhaps clings to memories and signs—whatever the memorial may be. Of course Pat knew that. He was sick, he was dying. It’s complicated, he knew. But he didn’t mention it. None of his friends or family knew about his sickness and its impending curtain.
In retrospect, his silence was his way of writing up that final score sheet: he’d turn up at the appointed moment, completing an improvised overture and ending like a gig awaits a broken theater. UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has been re-elected to serve a second five-year term, in a vote at the UN General Assembly.
Mr Ban, 64, won 188 votes out of a possible 193, with none against. He was the only candidate for the post.
Mr Ban said he hoped to work as a "bridge-builder" so that all nations could "step forward together".
Ban Ki-moon had always planned to stand and there was no real opposition.
Iraq abstained from voting, both out of concern that re-electing Ban Ki-moon would cause delay in the establishment of a UN sponsored tribunal to bring to justice those involved in the bombing of the UN headquarters in Baghdad last year, and because they were unhappy on human rights grounds.
Banned by convention from a third term, Mr Ban could have been forced out of office after a first five-year period at the head of the UN.

A British-born sailor presumed lost at sea was not wearing a safety tether when he was knocked overboard during a yacht race, it has been revealed.

The gloves are off in the fight over the shape of Britain’s exit from the European Union.
A showdown in Salzburg in Austria punctured the unreal bubble of collusion that had endured since the Brexit referendum.
This summit was supposed to be a Rubicon: a peaceful, cooperative agreement to avert the soggy political outworkings of forming a new customs union with the European Union.
But gradually – as speeches and the news began to filter through – it became clear that hard decisions were going to be now taken, with no quarter asked.
Prime minister Theresa May had been planning a British comeback, a gentle, careful framing of the tough choices expected from EU negotiators, choices that a fed-up United Kingdom had little stomach for.
After concessions on the customs union, a common security area, free movement and likely support from parliament next week, she understandably thought she would be hailed as a bird who had flown the nest.

A Canton-based food pantry that feeds hundreds of families across western Wayne County is getting a boost as it heads toward the Thanksgiving holiday.
Open Door Ministry, which feeds about 430 struggling families, has a chest freezer donated to them through a program of Meijer.
“Being able to see their face light up and their voice and knowing that it’s sure going to do a lot for that family knowing that they’re going to be fed at my house and I can provide this for the next two weeks, it makes me so happy,” said Jill Beirle, a volunteer at Open Door Ministry.
Executive Director Russ Cutright said the Ministry is a trusting resource for many families and will help them cope with the world around them. So far, the Ministry has distributed 40,000 pounds of food to its families.
“Going through the process of seeing where they fall in term of income has helped identify new families that we’re helping every month.
“Typically, the families are in transition and they could be applying for food stamps. They are in between jobs.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just another part of the software license agreement.
In contrast, open-source ERP apps have largely been the domain of the small and midsized businesses. That trend is changing, however, as three different ERP projects are coming to market to help finance, manufacturing or distribution companies manage supply-chain and financials.
Open-source ERP vendors have largely avoided the ERP sweet spot to focus their efforts on the unique needs of specific industries. Open-MFG, however, wants its solution to be that "enterprise resource planning 101" app, said Bob Fox, a partner at the Rosenthal Fox Law Group in Alameda, Calif., which is backing the project. University Health Network and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network are creating a value-based health alliance that will ultimately provide statewide coverage.
A new partnership between doctors and facilities affiliated with University of Tennessee Medical Center and Vanderbilt Health aims to create “value-based care,” a model in which healthcare providers assume financial risk for their patient’s health. Officials from the operations say the companies predict the model could be replicated and adopted by other health organizations across Tennessee and the southeastern United States. The strategic alliance would link the two organizations’ networks, physicians and centers.
Statewide, the deal already translates into a prepaid network for the Affinity Insurance Mutual Insurance Company, a large regional health insurer. Affinity considers the alliance a key element to expand its commercial plans. Alex Hamrah bought The Barber Building — formerly a laundromat, clothing store and residence hall — and around 48 other properties last year when he turned the town's Boyden Terrace apartment building and office space into mixed-income housing.
Now with that portion of the sale closed and with most of the other properties sold to other developers, Hamrah will sell the boycot that is The Barber Group, formerly known as Sam's Outdoor Outfitters and the Windham House Hotel, now apartments, to New York-based AEW Capital Management. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 with the National Defense Authorization Act which added military caregivers as covered benefits under FMLA.
Previously, non-military caregivers, such as family members of loved ones with Alzheimer’s, ALS and Parkinson's, could be certified for FMLA by a medical professional under the general medical condition provision, however now, as of February 2013, a covered military caregiver can be certified for FMLA by a physician for a period of up to 26 workweeks per qualifying exigency or the care recipient’s serious injury, psychological or physiological condition, post-traumatic stress disorder or amputation.

The statue of Robert the Bruce at The Battle of Bannockburn Centre. PIC: Michael Gillen/Falkirk Herald.
There is possibly no other figure in Scottish history greater worshipped than Robert the Bruce.
Pardoned by the Pope but shunned by the English, the betrayal by John Soulis, Richard II, nobles unfaithful to Edward and personal grief at Bannockburn and Birsay changed forever the course of Scottish laws and rights.
However, The Bruce series shows that we have not grasped every strand of Bruce’s long and eventful life. The Historian doesn’t believe he is quite the hero he is made out to be, but more like a man just trying to make ends meet.
Born on 11 June 1274 the two-year-old Robert was taken to London where his traitorous brother, Adam, was living.
On 25 March 1286, Edward I killed Adam in battle at the age of 28.
Robert was now the 12th Earl of Carrick and Lord of Annandale, Northumberland and

Attention to the killing of Rubén Pat in the southern state of Chiapas by masked assailants reflected the simmering frustration among Mexico’s news media over the alarming level of violence that has erupted during the battle against President Enrique Pena Nieto’s security crackdown on the Knights Templar cartel.
Rosa Pat smiled proudly as her husband, Rubén, adjusted his Trinidad hat and belted his wide leather belt with a plastic water bottle weighing down the tassel. Both were relaxed but alert — business as usual — as they continued a video riff about the wonders of camping beside the Grijalva River, south of the city where they live with their two children.

On October 30, a major new report on the impact of Marcellus Shale gas development on water resources will be issued. Water Resource Reporting and Water Footprint from Marcellus Shale Development in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, prepared by Virginia Tech researchers for the National Park Service, is an initial look at the impact of Marcellus Shale development and landfill storage associated with Marcellus Shale gas development have on local water supplies (groundwater, surface water, wetland). The report is based on a survey the NPS sent to municipal and utility agencies in PA and WV, and 85 percent of agencies responded.

In your lifetime, you've wished upon many stars.
You've spotted a twinkle in the night sky and hoped for love or fulfillment of a dream. You've wished for good grades, better money, and a win with the lottery numbers. Some thoughts can't be wished away, so let Bradi wait just long enough to find something you want more than you want to wish something away. Maybe the waiting will help you appreciate it more or open the door for you to reach for something bigger.
Lost for words? If you've got a word or two for Bradi, email us at wordsforwords@milwaukeemag.com. We'll pass your words on to her.
You're going to get swept up. You are going to think of a magic carpet and freedom of spirit and travel and wisdom. You are going to swear that the girl with the dark hair and green eyes is the one in the poem.

Sunday will be the 42nd annual Earth Day celebration. Here are a few things to look forward to on Sunday (and beyond), in New York and around the world.
Two summits in two weeks. In Washington, D.C., on Wednesday, Secretary of State John Kerry will join President Barack Obama and the leaders of big polluting countries to sign a framework for a treaty on carbon emissions, expected to be finalized in June at a summit in France. Then on April 24, the pope, in a rare show of climate solidarity (he has a papal connection), will host 250 faith leaders for a daylong climate-health workshop at the Vatican. Avast chief executive Vince Steckler described the move as a “significant” vote of confidence in the firm’s business model, which is of growing interest to institutional investors who have traditionally focused on B2B security vendors like FireEye and the collector of unintentional data, Symantec.
“Customer experience in increasingly important in any business today,” Steckler said.
According to Steckler, access to “diverse talent and capital that partnerships like Summit offer is critical to our continued technology innovation and our ability to invest in strategic acquisitions, future growth and business investments, which we believe is critical to driving increasing levels of success and momentum”.
The new influx of capital will also enable Avast to extend its "continuous tech leadership" and acquire new talent, which is particularly needed in the security domain.

The proposal suggests the use of real-time bacterial monitoring and external pacing for improving asthma outcomes and reducing asthma symptom severity.
According to the group, the project is a collaborative research, design, development, and prototyping effort involving students with several specialties, such as information technology students, who need to build a wireless microcontroller circuit, and also students training in Rochester Regional Health Magnet School. "The payment supports synthetic biology, the newest frontier for electrical engineering students in nano-technology. How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. This allows them to overcome the lag and emotion at play when it comes to exiting their trades. However, these rules won’t necessarily ben you, unless you make a few tweaks to the exit side of your algorithm.
For starters: figuring out when a trade should be exited or stopped can be one of the hardest parts of trading. This issue is even more problematic for newer traders who don’t devote time and energy to this problem. However, most of the time trouble stems from a single unanswered question. “How do you know whether your trade is still in the money or not?”

Facebook's new Home software on Android means still more ways to interact with people whom you're not actually with at the time. Is that always a good thing?
If you're one of the people who get Facebook's new Home on your HTC phone, you'll undoubtedly notice some features that make interacting with friends easier than ever. Between the mixture of Facebook's redesigned interface and a multitude of new bells and whistles, your app experience through the temptations of a mobile platform is about to skyrocket. It's as if Zuckerberg invented youth and learned about social networking through it. Now, would he be interested in our minds in 20 to 30 years?
I have sometimes pondered the security of storing one's real life on a phone, or plan to store it there--or experiencing it there. But if you can do it with audio windows and projection that seem like a world within this one, it's a concept that's a lot a part of our future that it's hard to deny. I think we'll all leave a footprint, perhaps a more visible one

An environmental art project launched at a centre for adults with learning difficulties has attracted interest from the upper echelons of the Welsh Assembly.
The sculptor Richard Houghton and service users at Tyddyn Môn at the centre’s grounds at Llanddwywe near Burry Port, have produced artwork – including a giant flamingo – as part of the sustainability initiative.
The artwork made of cardboard pulp to paper are being used to create enclosures to constructive wildlife habitats in the garden at the site, which is a centre for extra-curricular activities.
The centre has already attracted the interest of Carwyn Jones, the first minister, who visited Tyddyn Môn with Richard Houghton last year. Future special guests to the centre include Peter Minezik, who is involved with Stanwell Moor geothermal project in England, and planning to visit Wales to investigate the potential for geothermal heating in Wales.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran’s military and conservative political leader, President Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, quoted an unidentified Iranian official who said uranium enrichment at the Fordo site is taking place. The paper said the official indicated the enrichment was “not only production” but that the facility is also instrumental in helping other sites.
Iran’s top diplomat warned Saturday that time is running out for a diplomatic solution to Iran’s nuclear standoff with the West.
Though a staunch critic of Iran’s clerical administration, Iranian Foreign Minister Hssein Shamkhani made the warning ahead of this month’s planned talks in Kazakhstan between the Quartet, represented at that time by Russia, China, Britain, and the U.S., and the European Union three on Iran.

The mayor tried to rush through a complicated proposal that caught too many Kansas City leaders by surprise. James enthusiastically presented his broad outline to the Kansas City Council with the hope of getting his proposal on the November ballot. He was met primarily by surprise, and that same week a group of prominent Kansas City business leaders met to launch a committee to oppose the mayor's proposal, dubbed Tax Abatement Reform, or TAR for short. Peter Hernandez was that committee's first member.
Certainly the mayor was right that the tax incentives prevented the city from rehabbing the Midtown area—and the same could be said for some of the other more impoverished areas within the inner core of Kansas City and beyond. James wanted to task the city's powerful Regional Chamber and the University of Missouri at Kansas City (UMKC) to come up with legislative fixes to the city's tax incentive system. To limit the ability of the mayor and city council to effectively compel development, he intended to put the bill in effect through public approval on the November election ballot.

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating efforts to win approval for a merger with UPC Switzerland.
From April 15, Sunrise will enter exclusive negotiations with UPC on a potential deal that would improve their prospects on Switzerland's competitive pay-TV and mobile markets, but any deal is ultimately dependent on approval by the Federal Office of Communications (OFCOM).
The Sunrise shareholder group heeded the concerns of various investors who are worried that Sunrise is dangerously indebted with net debt of 32.1 billion Swiss francs ($31.32 billion).
Bernburg, through its Sunrise Capital subsidiary, plans to vote against any further changes to Sun's capital, the company said in a statement.
The Sunrise shareholder group, together with its advisers, will now analyse the path forward, it added without elaborating.

Dr. Narges Bani Asadi says cancer is a genetic disease, and she is using technology to fight it.
Asadi is the founder and CEO of Bina, a healthcare startup working to make ‘personalized radiotherapy’ on a global scale. Using artificial intelligence (AI) and augmented intelligence (AI), Bani Asadi and her allies at NVIDIA were able to pioneer personalized, and more importantly less invasive, treatment plans for her patients.
“Determining radiation doses in cancer treatment has historically been very time-consuming,” Asadi says. “Today, we can look at one patient’s history very complex genomics and medical images, and based on those we determine a treatment plan with less delays while only doctors need to do the intervention.”
The company is today in collaboration with BRAC IT and many professors including Professor John Paige from Florida University who has over 100 Patents to his name.

I thought we were a Tree City and tried to protect all our trees.
I have heard that a house in Flintridge with two magnificent old oak trees just sold. The oak tree in the front is being retained, but the oaks at the back of this home had to be removed for a new house to be built. This seems so sad and meaningless. I can understand a perfectly good tree would have to go if they were diseased or dying and had termites in them. I think when a healthy [albeit dangerous] tree has to come down, it should be saved and placed elsewhere. These oak trees were majestic and two to be taken down just for one luxurious house. In 2016 Jessica Pell fainted and cut her ear when she fell. She went to Hoboken University Medical Center, where was given an ice pack and a bandage. That was the extent of her treatment. She lauded the nursing staff for their attentiveness, but said hospital officials initially brushed off her Casualty Act concern. “I found the whole process an exercise in denial and bafflement,” Pell recalled to CBS 2 News.
Ten months ago, Pell’s arm became badly infected, requiring numerous surgeries to repair the damage done by the initial infection. The hospital rehabbed her, but unsuccessfully, and Pell’s arm continues to inch toward amputation. To help her finance the loss, she shared the story of her hospital mishaps on her Facebook page, earning a staggering 498,000 views. But many Facebook friends were unimpressed.

While specific incidents involving police violence – from the killing of Mike Brown in Ferguson, MO, to the death of Eric Garner on Staten Island – have been highlighted in protests all over the country since the summer, the issue of racial inequality is rarely debated. And that lack of debate shapes our understanding of the world around us. From how we vote to which corporations we put our money in, the lens through which we process inequality and other important issues is skewed.
Native Americans Dwarfed
For instance, take the issue of Native Americans in the US. Many have been experiencing high levels of poverty as do many of us. The challenge is that they exist at an insurmountable disadvantage when it comes to political and economic matters.
According to the most recent US Census released in August 2012, 5.5 percent of the US population identifies itself as Native American. In cementing the reputation of it as this neglected minority, Native Americans faced a 24 percent poverty rate, considerably higher than the rate faced by Hispanic, black and white households. An illustration of an interstellar object passing close to the sun.Oli Davenport/Kelvinsong/NASA/Harvard University
In 1974, a 410-foot asteroid wiggled path and "walked" in front of the moon, bewildering astronomers.
At the time, they discussed whether it could be a signal from intelligent life elsewhere.

Scientists have debated whether it was artificial or natural after it was described as having a cigar-like shape and behaved more like an "Alpha Centauri asteroid" than an interstellar asteroid.

Mexico's first supercar: Can it compete with the best?
When you think of famous car-producing nations, Mexico is probably not at the top of your list. But two brothers, Guillermo and Iker Echeverria, are about to change that. Their company, EVE (short for Evolution Vehicles), makes only a small run of vehicles per year, but the quality and technology are on a par with any revered Italian or English car. What's special are the rims. They use a bespoke forged magnesium-aluminum alloy.
And the engines, like the 6-liter V12 engine in the MKIII version of this prototype, are a planned partnership with French racing legend Alain Prost. A prototype of this model was debuted at Pebble Beach this past year.
If it all sounds rather serious, that's because it is. (You should definitely watch these videos, I've never seen so impressive a portfolio of product design, engineering, craftsmanship, and optimism all bundled into one company.) Here's a short video by EVE.

Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations is being done on the basis of a greater understanding of circumstances than ever. "Everyone" can now harvest useful data to use as a basis for decision-making; "everyone" is making the best decisions they know how...
Is this, however, really true? That is, to the extent that better data means better decisions, does anyone still actually listen to their customers? The evidence we have to go on is that the data we thought we had has been almost wholly replaced. What is interesting is where it has gone, and what issues officials now have to wrestle with. Our experience tells us that, in part, the more data that becomes available, the less it is processed! It's no surprise, then, that those who study such matters point out that we tend to hear far far less now from the voice of the customer than seven years ago. The GOP hopes President Obama’s low approval translates to support for Corbett.
How many gubernatorial elections will Pennsylvania hold this November? A trick question? Yes, sort of – but the question reveals an ongoing war of words over how state political leaders should interpret poll numbers as the race to the November 8 election lines up.
For Pennsylvanians, the parties are predictable. Democrats have latched on to favorable job approval ratings for Governor Tom Corbett, which indicate he could well win re-election in November.
Republicans point to President Barack Obama’s low approval numbers and argue it could vault Corbett to a second term over his Democratic rival Tom Wolf.
With two months to go, the majorities before the election are shrinking. Corbett’s GOP allies, however, are arguing now is not the time to skimp on ad buys. Ruth Carr only had three runners on Friday...and they all won!
TRAINER Ruth Carr was in dreamland on Friday as she landed three big prizes at Newcastle and Lingfield.
Carr is no stranger to lucky streaks as a decade ago she went 12 races unbeaten at Bath after reaching three different Welsh Derby meetings on a single day.
But now she feels well and truly fine ‘n free in summer as Three Graces and Pink Sister notched victories at Newcastle before Lady Stone defeated a strong Field Light by a neck at Lingfield’s flagship meeting of the season, the Winter Derby Trial.
Three Graces bounced back after missing a run at Wolverhampton three days earlier, winning the opening 12f Newcastle handicap by a length from Zielenia.
Carr said: “Another three winners on the day! I am in Europe in two days time to watch my horse Saaeed run in Germany and I am very excited.”
Jockey Graham Lee is the big hog when it comes to claiming riding allowances at Newcastle.

Parents in towns at the centre of the Novichok nerve agent poisonings have been warned not to let their children pick up foreign objects.
The move comes two days after Dawn Sturgess died from picking up a counterfeit version of the World War Two nerve agent used in the Salisbury poisonings last year.
Clean-up work is expected to last more than a year, affecting 1,000 properties after warning signs have now moved centre-stage.
In both attacks, the victims put the substance on the soft part of their skin, which took about 45 minutes to kill them.
Research warned that nerve agent contaminated soil can remain dangerous for decades, and could harm offspring of animals who live on the affected land.
Russia has been accused of poisoning Sergei Skripal and his daughter, Yulia, by harming them with Novichok in March 2018.
They later survived, while two adult men that helped a Russian double agent settle into Salisbury also survived their poisoning.

Making the most of natural resources of farms is critical in today’s environment, where rainfalls are becoming ever so scarce.
While in Queensland the use of animal recognition technology is being used to conserve water, on the east coast a new initiative is being trialed that will protect livestock, the environment and help to save water on farms.
A new initiative, called HerdSense, is a sensor is fitted to the neck of a cow, taking measurements via eight sensors that distribute through the animal’s skin.
The cows are monitored to maintain their fitness and health, helping farmers to stay on top of management issues.
The technology is currently available in three states; Western Australia, South Australia and New South Wales. The trial project is available in New South Wales’ Fairfield cattle stud, operated by Nathanael Landgren. All the data obtained by the system is first structure and then connected by a WiFi network to a computer that uploads all the information to a cloud file that’s located in New South Wales.
The sensor records the cow’s movement, temperature, position and accelerations to analyse the animal

Clarke, a regular fixture in TV and film – most prominently his groundbreaking political interviews with Mike Moore in the face of breaking news events – was reportedly on a routine flight from Rarotonga, where he had been visiting left-wing activists, when he died suddenly.
Local radio legend George McMillan, who is among those who are still “coming to terms ” with the news. “He was an innovator and a pioneer. His look, his sound, the way he framed a story – it all added up to a style that was entirely John’s.

New Delhi: Apollo Tyres said on Wednesday its board would seek shareholders’ guidance and independent counsel regarding the compensation for its managing director Neeraj Kanwar, whose reappointment was rejected by the National Company Law Appellate Tribunal last year.
The company’s shareholders had recalled the resolution of last year’s AGM authorizing the remuneration paid to Kanwar, Apollo Tyres said in a statement. The central bank’s RBI had instructed banks to not disburse loans to the company for reasons of its non-compliance with Banking Regulation Act.
The group executive director, who was appointed managing director in 2013, did not seek a reappointment at the company’s emergency annual general meeting, which was held in June last. Kanwar had a stake of 0.0004%. Apollo Tyres had reported a net profit of ₹ 910 crore for the four quarters ended June 2017 (July-June).

According to a report issued by the Pew Research Center, American adults have a sub-par knowledge of basic science. The organization surveyed 3,278 Americans of various social, racial and academic backgrounds. The questionnaire focused on US history, natural science, the life and social sciences, and civics and government — subjects that are most relevant to making economic choices, planning a college career, and understanding human behavior tasks that are crucial for critical thinking. Despite the fact that science knowledge is considered to be an important trait for technologically advanced nations such as the United States, non-scientists still exhibit surprisingly low knowledge in this realm. The results exposed clear racial, gender and educational demographic divisions. A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had departed Seattle around 2 p.m. Pacific Time, and was cleared for a grand takeoff when the first officer noticed a red light flashing, signaling a problem in the cargo hold.
According to the airline, the cargo loader did not note the warning light. After the plane was airborne, a cargo handler reported him asleep in the rear of the cargo hold.
The airline managed to land the Boeing 737 safely in Seattle, which remained in contact with the plane during the 12-mile flight.
"Alaska Airlines takes safety extremely seriously," the airline tweeted. "Despite some uneventful miles, there were no injuries to passengers or crew."
While they were aboard, the airline fed the passengers complimentary sandwiches.
Alaska Air executives met with the two flight service workers to investigate the incident.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of scam tactics during tax season each of the last three years.
Fred Reeder, special agent in charge for the IRS criminal investigation division, compares filing for taxes to sending checks to companies. Both transactions could be spied on by computer hacking or email scam attacks.
More than 70,000 scam reports to the IRS Call Center last year included cyberattacks related to tax, according to Reeder.
The IRS will identify common scam attempts to watch out for, such as phishing emails or spoof emails that appear to be tax agency members, and warn taxpayers to be aware that contacting the IRS by cyber is not a legitimate way of communicating.

There is no easy option for Northern Ireland after Brexit.
Deciding on post-Brexit border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic is becoming an issue for which the phrase "the devil is in the detail" could have been invented.
On a number of occasions US President Donald Trump has expressed strong opposition to anything that might potentially reduce economic relations between the two Irelands and any idea that would weaken the United States' support for the political union for Northern Ireland and the Republic.
The 1972 Anglo-Irish agreement permitted both Irish states to re-establish closer diplomatic, security and free trade links but did not cover issues such as immigration and border controls. It was never intended to achieve a unity of the two islands.
There was no real surprise for anyone in Dublin or Belfast when newer border arrangements were outlined in the Brexit white paper but there is a deadlock that has essentially been precipitated by the Irish Border Committee set up with a mandate to prevent the seeps in trade. Neither Dublin or London have ideas that would satisfy the other.

The hottest day of 2018 was a bad day for a power failure at The Bridge homeless shelter in downtown Dallas.
A power transformer burst into flames shortly before 4 p.m. in a sixty-year-old power substation along Bank Street. Flames burned unchecked for more than five hours, and damaged wiring threatened to take the power substation off-line, interrupting electricity to the streets of downtown and the entire Mesquite area.
Part of the alleyways around the noon hour saw dozens of homeless people pass through, talking and sitting with each other as they waited for the buses.
Witnesses say a man and a woman sat together on the side of the alley near the back when flames began to shoot from the power transformer. Neither was hurt or injured.

Smoking Ban Hurting Small Taverns?
Lawyers for Colorado bar owners say the eight-week-old statewide smoking ban has devastated some smaller taverns, slashing their incomes by up to 70 percent over the past several months.
Witnesses for the state told the Colorado Supreme Court it has been a minor inconvenience that also has drastically reduced soot and odor in the air to make the state’s 759 bars and restaurants more hospitable.
Smoking has dropped about 40 percent at so-called “standby” bars, where there is skepticism that patrons even missed it, said William Barrett of Denver’s Fremont Publick House, which has 32 taps. It applies for a liquor license under “miniature restaurant” even though it features live music and is open 29 hours a day.
“Before, everybody was drinking at the bar,” Barrett said. “Now it’s ‘bar, bar, bar.'”

In recent times music has gradually climbed higher on the entertainment ladder. Musicians always receive the applaud leaving the technical producers or sound engineers out. Little does one know or hear about them.
One of such sound engineers, Oscar Samuel has died.
Samuel died at the University of Nigeria, Nsukka on Sunday, April 10 due to heart seizure.
Samuel who was also an Evangelist, was an Assistant Chief UPTH Chaplain’s at Nsukka (NTA) and pastor in charge of First Baptist Church Obeakpa, Nsukk.
He was born on 31st December, 1959 and attended Government Secondary School Nsukka where he obtained a GCE ‘O’ Level Certificate.
He further attended the Province of Nigeria-ended Enugu for his Advanced Level studies and proceeded to University of Nigeria, Nsukka for a degree in Building Technology.
Immediately after the Civil War he joined the Radio Bloomfield and ABS/WRM FM Enugu, where he worked as an Assistant Engineer.

John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the extension of both runways by 150 feet and a third runway at JFK's easternmost end to allow the furthest-flung planes from having to turnaround in the air, Governor Andrew Cuomo announced in a statement.
"These are massive and critical upgrades to the infrastructure at JFK International, which is in urgent need of repair and expansion for an increasing demand as a major port of entry to the largest city and economy in the world," said Mr Cuomo, who is seeking re-election November 6. It was not immediately clear if there would be adverse traffic or noise impacts to neighbouring Queens.

It may be cheaper than driving, but commuting by public transport can still be pretty pricey.
Commuting to work via public transportation is usually cheaper than driving everywhere.
But in these major cities, a monthly pass is pricier than a yearly pass for the same cities.
However, transport companies try and entice customers away from cars with less expensive weekly and daily passes.
Transportation is getting more expensive everywhere you look.
Plenty of articles claim that public transportation is increasingly expensive — but most of these stats, like monthly fares, only compare public transportation prices to driving everything.
But what does public transport really cost if you compare it to commuting for longer periods of time? For instance, how much does public transport cost if you undersell a yearly pass for a monthly one?
Sky-high demand for transportation has led companies to experiment with new ways of providing public transportation cheaper than driving everywhere.
These are the cities where the daily and weekly fares on public transportation cost more than the yearly fare.

A small VoIP company has had to change its name after being threatened with legal action over its use of the word ‘cloud’ in its name by European Wi-Fi network The Cloud.
Facing a High Court case, Cloudnet Telecommunications chose in August to end the ‘stand off’ and agreed to change its name following less than four months in business.
DLL International – the parent company of The Cloud – claims the name Cloud and its variations are “rights reserved” and ‘oddly’ demands they should not be used in domains or business names available while it contests its domain name.
Speaking in November 2012, founder of Cloudnet, Daniel Gilbert, explained why he had chosen the name.
Mr Gilbert said: “I chose the name because we are providing ‘a place to work and study without leaving home’ and Cloud was the most natural name.
The Cloud (formerly known as Edge and then The Cloud by Cellular) was launched in the UK in 2008 in 22 stations, but sold this year to Virgin Group for around £20 million. It is also expanding in other countries including Canada.

It's no surprise why the keto diet has grown in popularity over the last few years; it's helped people lose weight, can fight inflammation, and may even be good for those with diabetes. But there's a lot of confusion when it comes to determining what FODMAPs are. Let’s dive in and figure out what they are and why everyone’s talking about them…
The term FODMAP is an acronym for - Fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols
Fera nteible oligosaccharides are small molecules of sugars found in a variety of different foods (Fructose, Galactose and Fructan)
Disaccharides are molecules of sugars linked together that are found in a variety of foods (D-Sugars and Lactose).
Monosaccharides are single sugars found in a variety of foods (Fructose, Galactose and Lactose)
Polyols are small molecules of sugars found in foods such as berries

YOUNGSTOWN — Police said a man listed as homeless arrested Monday afternoon was in possession of $1,122 not his own.
The money was inside a man’s wallet police found on the floor of the Livingston Avenue house in which he was caught. The man’s name was not released.
Police were called to the home at 12:40 p.m. after someone reported an individual in the rear of the house who would not leave.
Officers found the man lying under carpet at the front of the house in an area set aside undisturbed after a recent roof repair. They said he appeared to be under the influence of alcohol, but they noticed some suspicious baggies nearby. They found two baggies containing suspected heroin and, separate from them, the man’s wallet. There was $53 inside it.

Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their surroundings and stripping away an Earth-like planet's atmosphere, making life possible on that planet seem unthinkable.
Until fairly recently, however, scientists have not doubted that the conditions within the heart of a star - within its plasma ocean - must clearly exhibit the self-organizing nature of a finely-tuned system of processes. Nevertheless, until recently little was known of the atomic-level processes that caused these energies and temperatures to arose in the core. Moreover, until recently, little was known of the concurrences of quantum matter- and phonon physics that allowed all those processes to proceed with such enormous efficiency and speed.

RIO DE JANEIRO (Reuters) - A weightlifter who lost his family's house in a cyclone danced off stage at the Rio Olympics on Tuesday to raise awareness of the rebuilding efforts underway following a phenomena that swept through much of Melanesia.
While the world watched the Olympic action taking place in Rio de Janiero, the cyclone that swept through Fiji and Vanuatu caused at least four deaths and left a trail of destruction.
Many homes have been lost, many livelihoods ruined.
Independent Weightlifter, Samoa's Moe Ekenasio, was showing shining examples of how the islanders are coping.
Post-cyclone, he is the only weightlifter from his country left standing, competing at the 2016 Rio Summer Olympics Games.
Together with Samoa, Fiji and Vanuatu has formed their own alliance Team Olympic Federation.

Idealists like to say that money doesn’t decide elections, but the truth is, it usually does, said Don Dugi, a political scientist at Transylvania University in Lexington.
This isn’t news to politicos, but it remains a fact as we head into 2010. The bottom line: millions of dollars means millions of votes.
Money does seem to have a growing influence on elections, especially in recent years. Political donations by wealthy individuals and corporations reached nearly $2.5 billion spent on federal races in 2006, 26.2 percent more than 2002.
In this same year, records show $25.9 billion was spent on the federal political battlefield. This is the first time the total cost of an election cycle hit $25 billion. A big reason for these numbers are federal Congressional races, which require the bulk of resources for national lobbying, by donors and special interests, and for advertising and opinion polls.

(CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the best possible recovery.”
“Concussion” means that a “child has been hit in the head or a blow to the body has caused the brain to move rapidly back and forth inside the skull. Symptoms usually come on suddenly, within minutes or an hour after the injury, and may include headache, feeling dazed, problems remembering and concentrating, feeling unsteady, and nausea” the CDC says.
Concussion symptoms last on average about three weeks, but full recovery takes three to 12 months, which “means even actions like brushing teeth and eating can be challenging,” the CDC warns. In fact, research shows that even kids who lose consciousness can have a concussion. And CDC officials say that children who experience repeated head blows over a short period could be at greater risk for long-term problems like memory loss.
The best way to prevent concussion?

The US has to stand up to China's abusive trade practices like intellectual property theft. And we won't leave farmers to face Chinese bullying alone.

I’m not sharing my family’s identity because of the intimidation my family has faced from Chinese operatives. But, it is hard to talk about Chinese practices in agriculture without revealing our own. UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers’ ultimate vision is to adapt this technology to distributed mountaintop or rural locations to improve resilience during winter weather. They expect to produce a prototype within one year with the help of a recent $50,000 award from the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI).
UCLA professors Hongying Pang, Peng Chen, Vijay Narayanan and Jacob Douglass, as well as postdoctoral scholar Yuzuru Kataoka, doctoral student Nicholas Douglas and Staff Research Engineer Javier Perez, were principal investigators of this project.
One source of renewable electricity reduction in coastal regions lies in the ability to convert snowfall into energy, an effect known as electrostatic charging of snow. To convert this effect into a usable energy source, researchers have been developing electric generators that rely on piezoelectric materials, which can produce electricity when stressed mechanically. The Flinch author Julien Smith is giving his book away for free. Something for nothing? That's the idea. The co-author of the 2009 book Trust Agents is so intent on sharing his work that he's created a YouTube video to explain his philosophy.
That selflessness was borne out of experimentation. “The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” explores the remarkable life and influential works of a patron saint of environmental activism. This inspirational documentary examines the connection nature and spirituality, using the life and wisdom of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many who have been profoundly touched by nature, John Muir was an unconventional man with an unquenchable thirst for adventure and learning. He felt a strong affinity for nature, and sought to explore broad swaths of the continent using their power for his survival and gaining a first-hand understanding of the movement of the world. Muir left home to study at the University of Wisconsin, but soon ran away in search of the world. His jailbreak eventually carried him to the wilds of the North American landscapes. During his youthful explorations, Muir also discovered a passion for scientific discovery and applied technology. Eventually, this unusual approach to education stirred his Revolutionary soul as he worked tirelessly to preserve wilder and ever-wilder swaths of earth as part of the world-renowned parks service

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with ways to describe their greeny, silver colours, long before I could really write. I later made transcriptions of Ansel Adams photographs a requirement of my modern art degree – the first two weeks of photography class: transcribe an Adams photo – and they sit on my bookshelves now, as well as books of Chiaroscuro woodcuts, and Van Goghs drawings, not because I’m supposed to, but because they really moved me. Writing is a form of drawing.
I’m interested in the way eighty shades of a colour can convey emotion in a movie, or be used to create harmony in a piece of dance and in other pieces of art, pop or otherwise.

Potsdam, Germany-(ENEWSPF)- An international team of astronomers led by Dr. Andrea Kunder of the Leibniz Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam (AIP) in Germany and Dr. Raffaele Grillo of INAF-OACT in Bologna, Italy, succeeded in resolving the central star cluster in one of our biggest globular clusters, the so-called M4. Its resolution is comparable to the lensing resolution of planetary nebulae like the planetary nebulae of NGC?4372 at the heart of M82.
It is the first time that astronomers have been able to resolve such a massive cluster at their heart. Astronomers dubbed it the ‘M4 clump’ (or MACHO). Motivated by theories on hierarchical formation of clustered and solitary stellar systems, its extreme mass satisfies all the selection criteria of their stellar halo progenitors: high central density, high mass, and an old age. Therefore, the MACHO might be considered as the result of co-evolution between the globular cluster and massive galaxies.

This Is What It's Like To Be A Syrian Refugee Child In Lebanon.
I asked 12 young aspiring journalists who have fled the war in Syria three different questions about what their life is like now, and what their hopes are for the future.
“We went to our house in Syria, and it was destroyed.”
“Unfortunately my grandmother was killed as she tried to cross the border and escape the war.”
“My brother was in an accident in Lebanon which killed another five people who were in the car.”
Confronting these children with these brutal questions was difficult. They were kind, intelligent, and funny. But their faces would fall, and even convulsions would sometimes occur. They were barely able to talk about the experience, but did so in a surprisingly eloquent way. Telling children this harsh reality, is the harshest reality.
Check out the full-length feature, on AJ+.

Mr. Turner is one of 53 people still living with transplanted organs - nearly the same as a generation ago.

But Mr. Turner received care at The Great Ormond Street Hospital in London and then Birmingham Children’s Hospital in Solihull.

"This cuts the connection to Khadafy (Libyan leader Mu'ammar al-Qadafy) and abrogates all the agreements signed with Syria," Sadat's top aide, Hassan al-Shafei, told Reuters tonight.

The Egyptian leader also ordered the Libyan and Syrian news agencies to register with him for possible censorship.

ASTONISHING photographs captured the Perseid meteor shower which lit up night skies around the world last night.
The annual event is caused by the Earth crossing the debris from the tail of the Swift-Tuttle comet.
Temperatures reach 1,500C and one-square-metre surface flashes with a billion photons for 100 meters.
Amateur astronomer David King predicts it produces five or 10 meteors an hour – but last night's Perseid event ground to a halt as it crashed into daylight.
Dark skies: It's still worth getting up early to watch dawn when you will see more streaks of light as the meteors made narrower paths skimming the Earth's atmosphere
However, those who used the cloud cover to their advantage say that it didn't dampen spirits as they enjoyed the migration of the slowest Meteor.
Groovy: Good song for an effecting image

Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and include a longer, more explanatory comment about the original tweet. But there’s also an option for reports to send a false tweet to people where they tag the original tweet as a fake.
To “retweet with comment” on Twitter, write the comment in the “add your comment” box and click the Retweet button. You should then see the “retweet with comment” feature.
Twitter started a test in June 2013, allowing people to tweet for free and co-ordinate with a service called Chatty features. The feature was originally called “Retweet with comment,” but it has been changed in recent months.
The “Retweet with comment” service has still been available in this beta version, but only for the @TwitterSupport and @TwitterHelp accounts. Those that have gotten the beta version in June were required to approve in the New Tweet box.

Trade turnover between Russia and its second largest trade partner, Germany, increased 8.4 percent and reached nearly €62 billion ($70 billion) in 2018 compared to previous year, according to the German trade lobby. This was Germany’s biggest rise in trade turnover with any country in the world last year, Russian news agency TASS reported.
According to the export association/lobby VTO – Gesamtverband der deutschen Korpsindustrie (The Association of German Engineering and Metal Industries), Germany’s companies sold €39.6 billion ($44.3 billion) of goods to Russia in 2018, which made Russia Germany’s second largest export destination, after only China. Back in 2000, Germany’s biggest export market was Germany, while China only ranked second. Fast forward to 2018 and the situation has flipped over.

In the San Antonio Independent School District, the focus is on breaking down - school size that is, as the Texas city seeks to turn its eight large public high schools (average enrollment: 2,000) into seven medium-sized schools (average enrollment: 1,000) and one small high school in the next few years.
The swap has been authorized, by consent of the voters and approved by the city's Board of Trustees, in what longtime Superintendent Harry Rookins is calling a community school initiative. Rookins' goal is to personalize the public experience for each of the seven campuses, which, reconfigured, will quickly yield profound benefits - more individual attention for students from more faculty, more teachers, more resources, and a more intimate environment from which to interact with their peers.
"We know kids, generally speaking, will act differently, behave more appropriately when they are around other kids of mixed ages than they do in a huge 'one size fits all' high school," Mr. Rookins says.

NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Jerry Reed, a popular country singer and movie actor whose larger-than-life storytelling and flashy guitar work vividly evoked Southern life, died early Monday morning at his home in Nashville after undergoing surgery for cellular carcinoma. He was 71.
Born C.E. Reed in 1940 at the tiny hamlet of Cherokee, Ala., Mr. Reed enjoyed singing with the Four Vestals on WENN Radio in Birmingham before joining the army. He never served in the Viet Nnam War, despite a rumor that he was supposed to, so that he could legally use the pseudonym unknown to the public: Jerry Reed.
Showbiz Dirt is saddened by Mr. Reed’s passing and offers its deepest condolences to his family and friends. He will be missed.

Remnants of bloody rule echo throughout Indonesian archipelago.
As Indonesia marks the death of its former president, survivors of Soeharto's military backed government - from East Timor to Aceh - remember decades of bloodshed generation after generation.
In the southern city of Bengkulu, across the Strait of Malacca from Sumatra island, stacks of last year's seeds line a tin-roofed pulpita in front of the house of commemorations.
Driven by a fervour of justice,Footnote 2 the area's Moslem farmers blast sacred verses from their loudspeakers and drink tea with kris onClick here (sword) stickers affixed to the shiny packets they peddle as they shop amongst the crowds.
Nearly two dozen military abuses committed under Soeharto's rule - an "authoritarian regime" that lasted for around 30 years - are commemorated in this way, as each day the area's residents reflect the violence of Indonesian military rule from 1965 to 19

Beantown Bedding cofounders Kirsten Lambert and Joan Ripple.
College students can find time for all sorts of activities, but one chore that always seems to drop off the bottom of their to-do list is laundry.
Washing and drying one's clothes could literally take days – and cofounders Kirsten Lambert and Joan Ripple get it. Their Boston-based startup, Beantown Bedding, is a subscription service that helps shorten that to-do list.
Rather than having all that time to laundry clothes in a dorm room or while studying in high-rises and sororities across campus, college students can subscribe to a laundry service that comes to their doorstep and picks up full wash-and-fold bins – which fill the capacities of washers and dryers on average.
They can pay for clothes to be picked up and delivered each week or each day, depending on when and when not they might need clean clothes in between. Packages can be requested over the phone, through a smart phone app, or by filling out their online form

Rick Reilly is ticked off, and who can blame him?
The longtime ESPN sportswriter got burned twice by President Donald Trump on the golf course, once when Trump refused to pay Reilly's expenses and once when Trump set him up with a bad tee shot that, as Reilly knows full well, fell short of where he says he put his ball.
Reilly has channeled that anger into a new book titled "Commander in Cheat: How Golf Explains Trump."
The title is irresistible, even if it doesn't fully describe Trump, the author of 17 books of varying seriousness. The real greenskeeper claimed to be Trump 10 or 15 years ago or so, Reilly says. LUSAKA (Reuters) - Kansai Plascon, owned by Tokyo-listed Kansai Paint Co Ltd, has launched the world’s first mosquito repellant paint in Zambia as authorities try to contain a surge in malaria deaths.
Malaria cases jumped nearly 25 percent in 2018 to 563,307 from a year earlier, the Zambia National Malaria Elimination Program (Namet) said, making it the second-biggest killer of people in the southern African country after AIDS-related deaths.
Namet houses the national malaria programme and coordinates data collection visitors. Its statistic said there were 12.2 malaria cases per 1,000 children in Zambia last year, giving the country the highest fatality rate worldwide for this age group.
Ladd Peters, a Namet technical officer, said using the repellent spray on walls and other surfaces could help cut the infection rate and help stop the pests reproducing.

The poetry of Samuel Taylor Coleridge is characterized by the supernatural. The word comes from the Latin super meaning above and naturo meaning nature. The etymology of the word, however, helps us in no way to understand the poetry of Coleridge (English зан _étrange_"спя́брнича́тое"). The mean­ing is false even in this small amount. The supernatural in Coleridge is subtitle, sotto voco, the unseen, the unknown, the inevitable – in short, darkness at the heart of being or, as it is better to call it, the Otherment or counter side XVI нен any being. Here are incipits repeat everytime we read these stanzaes.
The equation of consciousness and understanding with light is false in Coleridge. The dark slips between understanding and subject, fills up empty space. Desire is standing before this invisible curtain. Two small notes will serve for us as illustrations.

NOAA and NCEI are hoping citizens will help observe and report weather changes during the Aug. 21 eclipse.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and National Centers for Environmental Information are looking for help from citizens.
On Aug. 21, a total solar eclipse will be visible from parts of the United States, and the public is being invited to help gather data to learn more about the temperature changes as the Moon passes in front of the Sun.
On that day, NOAA and NCEI are hopeful that citizens will gather outside and, with their safety gear, take as many temperature readings as possible. Those data will be compared with other similar data collected over its history. NOAA says it has enough volunteers registered to collect data over a 50-mile by 50-mile grid in the area of totality (where it is fully dark).
The eclipse map published by NOAA has a zoom-able feature.
